Bottle 750ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours hazy deep golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of apricot, peach, funky, tart and stable. Taste is light sweet and heavy sour with a long sour dry finish. Body is full, texture is thin to oily, carbonaiton is soft.
Hazy range body with a minimal white head. Fruity and citrus aroma. Taste is a good compromise between the sweetness of apricots and tartness of lambic. Nice one

2011 bottle, 04/13/2012.  Pours hazy golden orange, thin pillowy white head with large bubbles, recedes to swirly surface foam, fine sheet lacing around the glass. In the nose, pungent apricot yogurt and horse blanket, sweetly sour, thin mustiness, malts.  In the taste, upfront lemon tartness melds into tart apricots, acidic citrus, slight musty oak.  Intense mouthfeel, very tart and dry, yet somehow constantly inviting the next drink.  Very much a special treat, I prefer the more pronounced fruitiness of newer vintages compared to older ones.

Sample from a shared bottle @Schouskjelleren. Light orange colored, fully diminishing blond top. Strong lemon acidic aroma with a vinegary touch. Taste is substantially sour with a pleasant fruitiness underneath. Lemony and citrus zesty, hard to pin-point the apricot. Finishes bone dry with a mouth-drying sourness. Quite a challenging one.

750 ml bottle. Bottled 25 Aug 2008. Finland. 
 Hazy orange colour with tiny white head.
Sour fruity aroma with Belgian yeast, lead and mild touch of fruity sweetness. 
Flavour is very Lambic-y sour, tart and berry. Very tart berriness. Tart and sour aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  2005 vintage. Pours hazy milky yellow. Aroma:  very eggy, farty, sulfur ,gunpowder, oak, woody, rotten fruit, overripe fruit, apricot,  acidic  notes, bile, lacto acid, fatty yoghurt notes, Brett, barnyard, horse blanket, some fruity sweetness, vanilla, Taste:  high carbonation, fizzy, very fruity, you get the apricot, sour fruity, high acidity, lacto acid, some bile, very dry, extremely tart and sour, vanilla, oaky, sulfur, lemon, very dry, gun powder. Crazy! But really good!  Had the tap version as well and its completely different, not nearly as sour, and the apricot is a lot more present. Any who completely different but both good!

Bottle bought at the brewery.  Sour smell of apricots and similar citrus fruits. Very nice balance between fruitiness, sweetness and sourness. Very nice lambic! Worked great with a chocolate cake with cream.
Nice fresh fruity lambic. The apricot is somewhat difficult to find. Very nice lambic, though.

the fresh vintage is bursting with fresh apricot flesh aromatics with sour and low funk background. The aged vintages (when cellared well) become much more acidic, the fruit drops away without being completely lost. More funk develops over time but maintains balance with the rest of the flavors. I love this stuff!

2010 bottle. Pours slightly hazy gold with thin, fizzy white head; decent retention and spare lacing. Aroma is apricot, yeast, straw and cereal malt, sour fruit, and light herbs. Flavor is heavy fruit esters, mostly sour, with faint supporting malt; sweet finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Hazy orange with some pretty white lacing.  Light and tart apricot with a vein of vanilla running through it on the nose.  Very delicate.  In the mouth it is restrained with that beautiful fine-bead carbonation and a tingle of tartness which receeds rapidly to a lightly woody finish with some pukey fruit in the back.  Its great but not my favourite from these guys.  Works well with the cheese they sell at the brewery too.

0.75l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. Aha! Finally we meet (not again) but we meet! Fou Fone pours a light clouded quite orange-ish body. It has a small sidesticking just off-white head. The aroma is lovely tart with tons of lemonish sourness. Also tones of what best described as "old mans rope". Quite delicate and lemon overpowering! Heavy flavors on this one. Its quite zesty, heavy heavy lemon-sour! Om my god this is one sour lambic, but even thou its almost like sipping on a hyper-lemonade (without sugar) I somehow cantt stop sipping. Apricots? Well, if I hadnt know that it contained it I probably would not have guessed it. 10.03.2012

reviewed. 03-14-20122010 vintage. Pour was a pale murky orange, hints of grapefruit juice. Inch plus of creamy white head, held its place. Soft apricot with light sourness. Slightly funky. Taste is similar. Apricot is soft and subtle, but there. Nice light sourness up front. A bit funky throughout, blends well. Light and easy, airy body with a bit of pucker. Pretty amazing, would drink over and over.

750 ml bottle shared by Preismj morning after Hunahpu served with breakfast.  Poured a light cloudy pale orangish color, with aromas of tart apricots.  Really carbonated bottle, I believe from 2011, almost reminded me of alka seltzer water after each pour.  Flavors are slightly acidic, and tart apricots.  This was a real nice beer to have at breakfast time, and real glad Matt shared this one, first Cantillion Ive had, and now I need to try more.

17/12/2011 Ma che siete venuti a fà (tap). Bevuta a Birre sotto lalbero 2011. Dorata, torbida, schiuma bianca abbastanza pronunciata, molto persistente. Al naso ha il classico acido da Cantillon, un po sporco e tendente al citrico con una punta di acetico, che nasconde i sentori di albicocca. In bocca è acida, non eccessiva come altre Cantillon, abbastanza ben bilanciata, ma lalbicocca fatica a venir fuori. Corpo medio, carbonazione corretta. Migliora sorso dopo sorso, ma delude un po le attese.

Got this in a trade. THANKS RYAN! Went through extreme palate cleansing tactics prior to opening it up. Poured into a Flute and Ommegang Glass (sharing with the GF). Temp is about 50 degrees F in the glass. Bottle Date: August 18th, 2011

A - Beautiful orange bronze color pouring out of the bottle. Even on a slow pour, very champagne like bubbles rose to the top of the champagne flute and produced a 3 finger crystal clear head that subsided to a half a finger creamy line of bubbles on the top. In the glass, the beer resembles that of peach pulp with a perfect orange to brown haze and light clear bubbles around the edges of the glass.

S - Very light tartness on a first whiff. Delicious peach juice scent and some hints of tangerines and floral like lavender or rose petals. Of course theres apricot but Im getting peach. On the nose a very tart feeling hits the back of my nostrils and sticks around for a while. Very pleasant and not overpowering.

T - Naturally, the sour and tart hit the tongue first but theyre not intense like most Lambics Ive had. The 2nd bit is a waft of apricot. More of those really great floral scents. The tartness doesnt stick around very long. Its gone pretty fast. The traditional over tartness I get from non-Cantillons just isnt here. Its balanced, hints of very juicy fruits and terrific tartness.

M - The beer converts entirely to carbonation on a single mouth swish and more apricot pulp flavors are released on that swish. Linger is orange and tart and it fades away after a minute or so.

O - Sorry for the long review but I may never get this beer again. I may have hyped it up in my head a bit too much but this is still a phenomenal beer and one of the best lambics Ive had...possibly #1.

From notes.  First reviewed 8/9/2011.  Poured from a caged and corked 750 mL bottle into a tasting glass. 

This has a very elegant hazy golden yellow appearance in the glass. With its translucence it appears almost angelic, although I might just be thinking that because I am so excited to try it. A ring of white head rests in the edge of the glass, remaining mellow and not bothering to leave much lace.

This aroma is fantastic, just the perfect balance for a summer beer. A little bit sour, with just a hint of funk, there is a ton of apricot that screams refreshment.

The flavor is really a progression of apricot. Up front it starts sweet, like biting into a ripe apricot. It shifts to become more sour, gaining momentum from an acidity that starts in the periphery and eventually makes me pucker. On subsequent sips this sensation subsides and I distinguish some lactic sourness and a light mustiness at the end. 

The body to Fou Foune is light to medium, with a good amount of carbonation that is mostly creamy but provides a bit of crispy pep as well. Overall in line with what I want from a beer of this nature. Fairly dry and tart.

It is a cruel joke that this beer is so hard to come by in the United States. I am beginning to wonder if I should move to Belgium just to be able to drink Cantillon all the time. Seriously.

1/III/2012 75cl botle from Geers (Oostakker) @ Klaas place - 2011 vintage (2012-172) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Note: one of the lucky few Belgians to have sampled this. I mean, common, seriously one of the hardest Belgian beers to find in Belgium.
Cloudy light orange beer, small fizzy white head, unstable, dissipates immediately. Aroma: fruity and sour, typical geuze, almost sour kriek smell. No apricots though. Taste: pretty sour, distinct Cantillion flavours, lemon, lime zest, bitter touch and pretty fruity. Still no apricots though. Aftertaste: very sour, stinging, thirst quenching, slight touch of peaches or apricots, little bitter, lemon juice. So tell me again please, why is this hyped so much?

750ml green bottle, corked and capped. Bottled August 2011. Hazy, deep golden pour, white head with big creaminess and long retention. No lacing. Tangy, sour, musty but sweet nose, apricot-peach fruit notes with lambic vinegary-sweaty tang. In the mouth the beer has nice acidity, balanced by fruit sweetness. Tangy and sour end, dry with lots of acidity. Beautiful lively tight prickly carbonation, medium bodied. An excellent fruit lambic, one full of acidity and sourness, but nicely contrasted by the apricot fruits    sweetness. Very lucky that this beer has crossed my path, its a must try. Rating #1500.

750 ml bottle from trade with Kyle. Pours a cloudy apricot color with a small white head that quickly dissipates to zilch. The aroma is funky with tart fruits that remind me more of green apples than of apricots. The taste is rich and complex with a myriad of sour fruit sensations; i get, apples, grapes, apricots, grapefruit and mangoes. All nicely sour and funky. As I progress through the bottle the apricot flavor, which was barely discernible at first, gets bolder and bolder. The palate is full and silky smooth with lively carbonation. Finishes long and pleasantly sour with an aftertaste of big bold apricots. Overall: Lambics are not my strong suit, and sometimes I question whether or not I could spot a good one. All I know is that I really liked this.
the best cantillon ever.... la presenza consistente di albicocche si sposa perfettamente con lacidità di questo stupendo prodotto...

On tap at the Beer Revolution Anniversary.  Pours a cloudy orange with a small white head that settles to a ring and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big apricot, some lemon funkiness, lactic, along with a bit of sweetness.  The taste is tart with a bit of initial sweetness.  Lots of apricot, tart lemon, signature Cantillon funkiness.  Finish is tart.  Medium body.  Low carbonation.  The fruit is really prominent here, more so than in other Cantillon lambics.  It also has a bit more sweetness than other Cantillons, but certainly not too much.

This beer gets all max scores from me. The best I have ever had. Big thanks to Shades of Gray for opening this up at our Darkness Day tasting

Smell is super pungent of funk and apricots. I believe this was an 07 vintage so the apricots were not as up front as they would be fresh but I could still detect them. The taste is un parallel WOW the most sour and balanced beer I have ever had. I would love to get another bottle or 50 of these and just sit on them. The best and well balanced sour I have ever had.

First pour before before I add the sludge, beer appears like golden apple juice with a tall very fizzy very noisy crown. Couldnt wait for the aroma I needed a sip.....super dry and super puckering. First aroma I hit was sour pear with a touch of egg. The egg has vanished and morphed into an apple. Im not detecting the apricot as strongly as I thought I would, its there but it mingles in with the other fruit aromas. The aroma has a funk and  I like it. Taste is so dry and tart...................lip smacken good. Apple, funk, leather, apricot, the sour lingers perfectly on the tongue. This is an easy beer to drink. Light bready malts seem to keep the sour in check......but I think the sour is winning. Took a 20min beer break and the after taste seemed to turn to vinegar. Just poured the last half of the bottle and beer looks tan/grey/ and not clear at all. Aroma has much more pronounced and sweeter apriocot now. And WOW!! the taste got 10X more funky and sour. Strange aroma got milder but the taste got harsher. I like the funk so much in this beer not to harsh not to mild. Great beer!!
Holy apricots!  This one is the bees knees.  Super apricot and nicely tart with the right amount of funk.  Top notch and the best fruit lambic ever.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2012 Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1. Vintages 2005 and 2011 side by side. The 2011 is much hazier, the 2005 more clear. Dark golden. 2005 was more carbonated.
The 2005 is much more tart and sour, almost like a geuze and not a fruit lambic but you do get some distant apricot, mostly in the aroma and very faint as a flavor. The 2011 was a fruit orgasm, fresh apricot aroma and flavor which was absolutely fantastic. I preferred the 2011 but I am currently being introduced to the sour world :D However the 2005 was quite lovely too, On the label though it says that it is recommended to try it within a year of production, so the fruity experience is what the creator had in mind. So therefore i will score based on teh younger sample. (The 2005 version was 8-3-8-4-17 = 4 for my taste).
Bottle at Blue Monk, Buffalo. Mimosa like colored pour. Funky aroma. notes of ripe pungent blue cheese. Light BC in flavor, apricot, buttery, citrusy acidity. Great stuff

Draft @Local Option.  Poured pale hazy yellow with huge head and a great cap.  Aroma is sour funky gueuze with apricots, very floral if one-dimensional.  Taste is damn near perfect; could drink it all day if Cantillon was ever regularly available....  Body is light and effervescent with a bone-dry complex funkadelic finish.  Overall, this is freaking delicious!

Good thing this is bubbly or the Alberta Carbonation Police would be knocking at my door. Poured out a hazy light... well I guess I actually have to call it apricot in colour with a large sizzling white cap. Interesting mellow aroma: minerally, warm apricots.. the apricots change with density and sweetness as you inhale the goodness and jam your nose deeper into the glass. The sweet side comes out the strongest just before you fill your lungs all the way. Mellow apple and a sweet bread side with the sour notes not making too much of an impact. After a lengthy sit I almost got tricked into thinking there was mushed berries in here. Trippin to Herbie Hancock - Inventions & Dimensions. The taste is very, well, tasty. Bready finish with permanent sour lingerings. Sour tartness that does not kill yet leaves some dryness and a need for perpetual mouthfuls. The sweetness of the apricots seemingly keep everything in check, light light funk, sourness without the attitude, crab apples with some attitude. This smells way more like physical fruit once I dumped in the sludge. This be good yum. I dig. good carbs, good everything. Through my Olivia kaleidoscope it looks even better than before... maybe this how peeps give it a 5 on appearance.

Bottles @ FoneFan:
2005:
HAzy dark yellow with tiny white off-white head. Aroma is malt, tart, barnyard, little apricot  and fruit. Flavour is malt, little sweet, fruit, barnyard, tart and a little acetone. 9/3/8/4/17
2011:
Hazy dark yellow with small off-white head. Aroma is apricot, fruit and berries. Flavour is malt, wheat, fruit, apricot, tart, little citrus, little sweet and a little dry. 9/3/4/8/16

Pours cloudy orange with a white head. The aroma is very tart with apricots showing through well. There is sharp citric acid, wild yeastiness, crispness yet smooth. Medium / light body thats very crisp and has flowing prickly carbonation. The flavor starts with dried apricots, citric acid, lemoniness, spice and funky grains. The finish is sour and tart with less apricot and lots of lingering citrus and funky bugs. A great lambic.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting... Poured a pale, orange/yellowish with a white head.  Nose had Cantillon funk and brett, horse blanket.  Fruity, eatery, wild yeast spices, ginger, lemon, tart acidic apricot flavors.  Crisp, very quenching.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2012 Bottle (dated 25 Aug. 2011).

Hazy golden with a short sizzling white head that doesnt lace.

Aroma: Baking powder acidic with sharp citric acid, ammonia, wet moldy wood and brie cheese rind.

Taste: Astringent and aggressively acidic with wood, lemon, slight hint of ripe apples, green apple zest, sharp note of brie rind. Baking powder.

Mouthfeel is a bit thin with some watery notes and a battery acid kind of carbonation.

Very aggressive and a bit thin, and I have a hard time finding the apricots. I had hoped for more from this one. [7/4/7/3/14=3.5]

Draught @ Akkurat during SB&WF 2012: 
Very different vibe from it this time. Heavy sour lemony/grapefruit nose with a lurking note of apricot and funk. Taste is very sour with grapefruit, lemon and  sulphur. Then in the aftertaste the apricots shine with a long nice fruity dry vibe. Medium bodied with light dry liquid and quite hard carbonation. Lovely!
[8/4/8/4/15=3.9]

smag på samme tid og er meget forsk.i smag super opleves prøve ny og gamle 
2011
Aroma:blomst abrikos  Ud.:gylden uklar Skum: lidt  E.smag:sød lidt sur moderat Krop:medium For.:tør Brus:meget brus 
 9 4 8 4 17 
27/1-12 @f1 
2005

Aroma: citrus grape læder Ud.:gylden klar  Skum: lidt E.smag:sur moderat eddike
 Krop:let til medium For.:tør Brus:livlig 
7 4 6 4 16 
  27/1-12 @f1

On tap at the Local Option. Pours a hazed, gold-yellow colored body with a finger-width, foamy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is bigger apricots with a nice tartness, some perfumey citruses, a light funk, apple, a bit of an acidic sharpness, dry hay, and a touch of musty bread. Flavor is similar. Lots of tart apricots with a nice sweetness and funk, some oak, peach, slightly sharp citrus acids, and a light bready malt backing. Some straw towards the end as this finishes very dry, crisp, and refreshing with a solid tartness with lots of apricots, some citrus, and funk as well as a touch of malt backing. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium-light body and medium-high, lively, tingly carbonation. Overall, a really nice beer. Fairly sour, but balanced with a nice sweetness to the apricots and funky citrus. Very clean and refreshing. Very happy to have tried this on tap.
Bottle I brought back from Belgium.  Sour aroma, acid, peach.  First sip is very sour, but mellows out as you keep drinking.  Great peach flavor.  Awesome brew.

Bottle shared with Bill and Matt at Avenue Pub. Pours a cloudy orange with small off white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is fresh apricot, man i just wanna live in there. Thin mouthfeel with a sour apricot, very refreshing. Wow reallt enjoyed this one.

bottle courtesy of Ems work(ass kissing) friend. POP! goes to cork. Pours a hazy golden hue capped by a light color head. Bubbling carbonation. Light and efervesant(sp?) nose. Puckering sour on first sip. Gobs of funk and brett. Mellows out as your palate adjust. light appricot skin flavor. Very light bodied.

Rated via BeerBuddy

Appearence: Cloudy gold
Aroma: apricots, farm, hay
Taste: Apricots and sour complex finish
Overall: A delight to drink

8/25/08 bottle. golden orange, hazy body with small white head. aroma of sour must, large funk, tart apricot, and some oak. extremely sour flavor with huge apricot, cantillon funk/yeast, oak, and basement...

Bottle at home, from my trusty old Mauydite gl;ass. Shared with Cole. Pours cloudy gold, 2-finger cream-coloured head, ropey lacing. Nose is apricot/peach, one of the first times Ive really gotten the "intended" fruit character so strongly from a lambic. Notes of sweat, earth, funk and cheese, very nice balance between the fresh fruit and the funky lambic. Flavours of stonefruit, cheese, salt, funk, really nice tartness. Awesome brew!

Sparkling, pale yellow to orange and hazy beer with thin vanishing head. Sweet and fres apricot aroma with medium lactic acidity. Less apricoty flavor but they still give good fruitiness. Acidic, citrusy and tart flavor also had some red currant notes, well developed and dry woodiness. Mouthwatering, acidic palate is medium bodied and waxy/sticky.

75cl bottle @Kaisla 5.1.2012. Poured hazy golden with a thin head head. Barnyard, apples in the sour aroma. Flavor is very sour, barnyard notes, fruits and woody notes as well. Very dry. Another superb beer from Cantillon!

Pour from a bottle and just slight pop of carbonation as the bottle was opened.August 2011 vintage. Orange gold in color. Solid funky wild earthy aromas after the beer opened up a bit.  The apricot flavor was solid and not way too apparent. No residual sweetness. Natural fruit flavor with additional peach and lemon.Very easy to drink. Tart sourness and no real acetic vinegar character. Really tasty.

Bottle dated 2008-08-25, shared by badnewsbeers. Murky apricot (fitting) orange-dirty brown body, thin ring of off-white carbonation. Sour nose, cobwebby with horseblanket and stomach acid, rather dry, also tart apricot pulp. The body hits with a nice sour punch with prominent meaty, full apricot flavors, the distinct apricot character a refreshing complement to the clinical sour, dry cobwebby character. Excellent beer, probably my favorite Cantillon.
Wow, great lambic.  Lots of apricot sweetness, especially on the back end.  A little yeasty too.  Fantastic beer.

This poured a semi murky straw yellow color with a white head.  Aroma was medium funk, tart apricot and some yeasty notes too.  Flavor was more apricot sweetness than expected.  Medium tartness and light funk. Very nice.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2015 Had this at the 2011 Pittsburgh Ratebeer Christmas Eve Eve Tasting.  Lithy, this beer ROCKS!  Fortunately I was present when this was popped.  Smells like any good canty and it looks a little cloudy and pale.  Tate is yes, sour and a little soda pop apricot.  Sizzling lovely lambic, the real beers of the beer styles. Puckering at times along with more sizzling tartness. What else can be said about this brew?  Each sip is simply lovely real beer fruit lambic, the kind that is not overly sweet.  What a really nifty chance at tasting beer!  Thanks Justin, I owe you big time.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle, 2011 version. Hazy gold with a white head that fades to a coat. Aroma of wheat, apricots, almonds, vinegar. Taste has apricots, apple vinegar, lemon. Some seeming sweetness underneath the sourness before a dry and slightly woody finish. Quite carbonated, but underneath theres a light kefir-like texture. Subtle flavours under the sourness and very refreshing. Curious how the apricots pop in and out of prominence on the palate.

2011 bottle, lightly hazy orange-yellow, whitish cover.  Aroma is peachy, fleshy fruit, lightly, faint tartness.  Taste is nicely sweet, fruity, flesh stone fruit.   I think it is a tasty beer, I would have personally preferred more tartness.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2016 750ml bottle @ Gloria, Kuopio2008 vintage - Pours orange with a light white head. Aroma has notes of floral notes, fruits, berries and malts. Taste is sour and has notes of berries, fruits and spices. Finish is dry and sour. Okay, but not the best Cantillon I?ve tasted. 8-4-7-3-15 = 3.7

Re-rated on Zwanze Day 2014,  draught @ Pikkulintu. Wow, much better from a fresh tap. The apricot notes are really noticeable here, and this is smooth, fruity and nicely balanced. 9-4-8-4-16 = 4.1. Re-re-rated on tap @ Stadin Panimobaari, 2016 vintage. Feels a lot smoother than I remembered. Really fresh and tasty. Great.

Bottled: August 18, 2011. Poured into a tulip glass. 

A - This body has a cloudy, almost syrupy appearance to it. The color is somewhere between gold and pale orange. There was a short lived white head that led to some tight edging. Swirling yields some lively carbonation and some lacing. Looks fantastic!

S - As soon as I popped the cork I could smell the apricots. Super intense apricot aroma. It smells more like the dried variety than fresh apricots, as it almost has some candy notes to it. The finish is fairly acidic with a touch of brett funk. You can tell this is going to be a sour beer.

T - More of that dried apricot sweetness. Just a massive fruit presence. The finish is sour and acidic. Not a lot of funk or brett flavors to speak of. A bit better than the aroma.

M - Very lively and spritzy. The carbonation is perfect, and the body has some weight to it which is great for these flavors.

O - This is the best fruit lambic I have ever had. It really captures the apricots, and I cant imagine aging this any longer as the fruit sweetness is perfect. However, its not as mind shattering as I thought it would be. Is it worth $28 and the hunt of landing a bottle? Probably not...but it is delicious and really well made.

Bottle, thanks Dak for sharing! This beer The apricot is very present in its aroma right off the bat. The apricot also comes through on the palate. The head seems to be present only on the outside of the pour. The color is a light good representation of the beer. Sour, not too much, but definite a good level for the fruit in the beer. Amazing.

Bottle. Stored for a week on its side and then upright for 3 days. Perhaps it should have been upright longer as i get a strong dustiness to the beer. Cloudy apricot colour with a soft white head. Soft, lightly sour fruit scent. Sourness is strong at first but then becomes as much a part of each sip as the solid apricot flavour. As stated a little dusty and a sense of yeast. Very nice and enjoyable. Pricey though! Had to go back in to add a comment. It seems like the creamy apricot gets stronger and tastier with each sip.

Bottle shared by birchstick. Thanks a lot Jon! 8/18/11. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is lemon, barnyard funk and maybe a hint of peaches. Flavor is vinegar, funk, apricots and tart lemons. Medium bodied with a dry finish.

Tried this twice in the last 2 months, another great tasting beer from Cantillon. Tart and funky aroma, with a bit of fruit, more fruit in the taste with a little hint of red vinegar. Love the look and taste of this beer, will be on the lookout again.

750ml corked bottle pours a golden orangeish color with about 2 fingers of white head that leaves some spots of lacing behind.  Aroma is a mild fruitiness.  Taste is quite tart and dry apricot with a sour finish.  Light to medium body and adequate carbonation.  A decent lambic ale at best.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2012 Bottle shared by birchstick- thanks, Jon! Bottled 8/18/11. Pours a pale, somewhat hazy yellow-gold with a small white head that rides it all the way down. Aroma of lemon, white grape skins, not-quite-ripe peaches, yogurt, and dusty funk. Flavor of sour lemon, peaches, and apricots, vinegar, musty funk, and yogurt. Light-medium bodied, with a sour, dry mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Lovely and tasty. Re-Rate, STLWills 30th birthday party. 2001 vs. 2011. Not much to add to my 2011 rating except there was a lot more apricot in it than I remembered. The 2001 doesnt have so much of that apricot, but more of the sour, tart, funky punch to it. The 2011 is more crisp, carbonated, herbal- I also found it more complex and fun to drink, but just by a little.

Pours a cloudy light peach color with a fluffy bubbly head.  The nose is wonderful, lots of a fresh earthy mushroom, lambic funk, touch of leathery brett, notes of dry oak, strong peach and appricot sweetness in the back.  The taste is great, very funky, earthy mushroom funk, a touch sweaty, bright peach and appricot flavors with a faint sourness in the finish.  Medium body with a lively carbonation and silky smooth on the palate with a rather dry finish.

An orange-hued pour with an ample head. The head is white and falls fairly quickly. Lacing is present. Huge aroma of apricot/peach. Had this one fresh a month ago and it was even more apricot scented. It fades quick. Funk and earthy. Tart and sweet mouthfeel. The apricot flavor is still there, but when fresh it tastes like apricot juice. Of course, that is mixed with the funky flavor that is present in all the Cantillon line. Not sure what to make of the age on this. I like it fresh, but it does still taste good with some age. The couple year old one I had did not really have any apricot flavor or aroma left in it. But the freshest one I had was really good too. Oh well, still an excellent beer.

750 ml bottle bought @ Ølbutikken. 2011 vintage. Shared and consumed on November 18. Pours hazy golden orange with a fluffy white head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace on the glass. Smell is sour and fruity with apricot, grapefruit, hay, leather, green apples and yeasty funk. Taste is dry, sour and slightly sweet with tons of apricots. Theres also some orange zest, sweet red apples, stomach acid (in a good way), leather and yeast. Finish is dry, slightly sour with leather and funk. Very nice but in retrospect I think I should have cellared this for a year or two.

Huge thanks to PaulUnwin for sharing this one.  I appreciate your generosity.  Pours a hazy yellow with a small white head.  Nose is apricot, peach, funk, vinegar, pepper, salt, and a hint of crushed aspirin with bits of citrus hops.  Flavor is similar with fruit all over- apricot, peach, and vinegary citrus with funk.  Light to medium in body and overall a symphonic beer.

11/11/11. 2010 750mL courtesy GT2! Very cloudy apricot colored pour with a frothy off-white pour that cuts but sticks and laces plenty. Funky, fruity aroma with a bit of apricot, acid, and wood. Huge tart flavor with acid, wood, more tartness, a touch of peachy fruitiness, and more tartness. Holy tartness, Batman! Good stuff!

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 Bottle thanks to bro from the other site, looks murky no lace little retaining head.

Aroma is big on apricots, some funk, barnyard, tart, the balance is really what is crazy impressive

Taste, the apricot flavor is constant but the tart funk has a parabolic trajectory. The finish is apricot. Fucking amazing

Enbotellada en agosto 2011.Color naranja con un poco de turbiedad.
Agradable corona de espuma que persiste.
En nariz es puro albaricoque,Que acompaña hasta el final.Acidez poca,en comparación con otras.Muy agradable de beber.Magnifica

My best Lambic fruit. Fantastic fresh apricot smell with a little earthiness. It smells like country. The taste is apricot, apricot, apricot, and a slight lemony sourness. It so easy to drink, so refreshing, so well done. a must have Lambic !

750mL 2010 split two ways.

A - clear golden with a finger of white head, a few spots on the glass.

S - fresh apricots, lemon, a touch of oak with even less funk apparent in the nose. 

T - Delicious ripe apricots, peaches, tart green apples, lemon rind, and a lingering funk. Very bright but well balanced.

M - light body and carbonation glides over the tongue and finishes crisp and dry.

The first time I had this beer it was 6 years old and it was a sour bomb. The fruit was barely kicking, but it was still enjoyable. I would have to say I prefer the fresh bottles for the great balance of sweet and sour. My favorite fruit lambic to date.

2011 bottle. Pours a nice orange color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is really tart, filled with tart apricots, sublte peachy notes, along with vinegar and some funk like barnyard and musty notes. Taste is really sour with lots of apricot and peach notes, I also get a subtle green apple and white grape flavor, subtle citrus, along with vinegar along with barnyard funk and musty notes. The body is light with a dry mouthfeel. Overall one amazing fruit Lambic, in the same range as Blåbær!

Draught at Mikkeller Bar. Copenhagen. Zwanze Day, 17th September 2011.

Keg from August 2011 so the fruit characteristics was well preserved

This is hands down the most refreshing, appealing fruit lambic Ive ever tried. It portraits the apricots in a stunning way. The aroma and taste is just filled with fresh apriciots and on top of that some earthy mineral and herb notes. Its funky, sour and just devine. I had 4-5 or five glasses of this and if it wasnt for the train I had to catch I would probably have gone for 5 more!

Draft @ chez moeder lambic / stone fest 
Head: almost none 
Colour: blond 
Smell: Geuze, malts, yeast, peachy, sweet 
Taste: peach, yoghurt,sour,fruity, apricots, end is sweet/semi dry and very fruity , nice one !!

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2011 Tried the 2011 vs a 2008. The 2011 has alot of apricot faroma, together with much apricot taste. The 2008 has lost much of the apricot aroma/taste, but has the old very sour Cantillon taste. Now the thing is, you just need to mix those two together and create your own Zwanze, its the best of both worlds. A nice old sour Cantillon with lots of caracter and the great apricot aroma and taste. Finish this with a little bit of a good white whine which aged on an oak barrel and youve created your own blend.
light fruity sour aroma,yellow,cloudy, white foam, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, light marelice finish.

Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Funny apricot aroma, faint peach too. Fruit. Dark yellow and hazy. Has a whiet head, fully lasting. Flavor is light sweet and moderate acidic. Dry texture and light astringent.
Bottiglia da 75 comprata allIrish e bevuta a casa, abbinata con riso venere al salmone, vero e proprio matrimonio damore. Fantastica
From tap. Poured a beautiful golden. Started off tart but never got truly sour. Apricot, lemon, yeast. Dry finish.
UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 Nose is heavy barn yard, little cake, decent sour notes, feel is watery, carb  is mediumweak, taste is some bile, mediumbroad bittersweet hops, some sour apricot notes. 2007.

Seichter, dafür natürlicher und etwas süßer Fruchtgeruch. Im Antrunk überwiegt dann natürlich die Säuerlichkeit, die zwar gering startet, hier aber schon einen minimalen Essigton aufweist. Im Verlauf wird die Säure aber auch die Fruchtigkeit intensiver, hierbei behauptet sich die Aprikose erstaunlich gut gegen die nun intensive Säure. Die Essignoten flammen dann wieder auf, so wird die Fruchtigkeit dann doch noch in den Hintergrund gestellt. Zum Schluss dann auch Zitrone, im Nachgeschmack sehr trocken. Ein von vorne bis hinten intensives Bier, ich habe selten zuvor ein so saures und dennoch ausgewogenes Bier getrunken. Zudem kommen die Fruchtnoten gut zur Geltung. Genial! 13/14/13/14/13/14

This one pours a nice yellow that was slightly peachy coloured. the aroma is sweet and refreshing. the taste is quite nice is good, I would like to try this one aged to let the sweetness down and the sourness to come out

Had both an 05 and 08 @ Daks Cantillon Tasting.  The 08 was, by far, the most sour, jaw-locking, mouth-puckering, eye-crossing brew Ive had to date.  If you havent had or enjoyed sours before attempting this, you literally might implode...and I dont want to clean that up!   Aroma and flavor show tons of lemon peel, grapefruit pit, tart unripened apricot/peach, and oak.  Imagine biting into a slightly green/firm apricot, scraping your teeth against the pit.  You make a face but want to take another bite, dont you?

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Moeder Lambic  über-fresh 2011 version, made only a couple of days ago: murky yellow, light orange with a super firm lambic-head which sticks around even after you have drank all of the beer, smell is fantastic, pure apricots, not tart or sour but just pure apricot, taste is incredibly dry, jam-packed full of yeast, almost flour-like, initial taste is tart, minor barnyard & hint of lemon, soaked into the mouth filling thick tart/wild yeast/flour-taste & body, aftertaste is a sudden and unexpected resurgence of fresh apricots, no real sourness has even developed yet here, liking drinking straight from the cask at the brewery which is more or less what this is, curious as to how something as this would develop because this young, it is still completely off the beaten path ///// had a 2012 bottle of this one and on draft - this years is so good even if people say the previous one was better - it is like pure apricot compote - like the liquid in canned apricots - some sourness lemony in the draft version I must say /// upped score from 4.5 to 4.9 - so damn good right now this stuff - drank a bottle and wanted a second one directly 2013 /// 1 month old. Still getting that feel of Pure Apricot 2013 in this, already very heavily lactic, this has the complexity that 2012 had @ 1+ yr. old already now. This may be less astonishing than 2012 was fresh but is going to age into something incredible whilst the 2012 was top fresh.

From Lautre Oeil. Bottle.
Pours very light, yellowish, very small and light white head with a pretty good retention. Looked extremely fizzy (3)
Aroma is a bit overwhelming on the side, as far as sourness-to-come is concerned, but apricot is still pretty perceptible (....obviously). Taste is borderline overwhelmingly sour with an heavy dose of apricot == things becomes interesting when you can taste the subtles wine, wood and vanilla. You have to work, though. The finish is probably where it gets even more awesome, with the wood taking as much place as the apricot. (8)
Really watery mouthfeel and reasonable carbonation -- lets face it, to much carbonation on this one wouldnt work at all. .... Extremely sour.(4)
The Foufoune is great. Still, you have to know what youre ordering/drinking first - accept the sourness. Im happy I havent drank this one 12 years ago, as I wouldnt have fully appreciated it. (15)

Drucken på fat på Mikkeller Bar. En riktigt tuff lambic. Två år gammal som fått dra med aprikoser i två månader innan buteljering. Riktigt stram, liten sötma, inte mycket aprikossmak. Snarare syrliga citrus frukter, bra beska, den där sträva syrligheten från omogna äpplen. En fantastisk dryck.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2012 (750ml bottle).  We had an 05 and 08.  I ended up rating the 08 because it had more of the apricot and was considerable more sour than the 05. Pours a hazy light golden color with a slight white head.  Aroma is dried apricot, vinegar, funk and wood.  Taste is super sour and a nice, gentle apricot flavor.  Medium bodied with a dry, woody finish.  This was a great beer and one of the stars for me on a day that many big, big beers made an appearance.

09. Bottle at Moeder Lambic in St. Guilles in Brussels. Golden yellow color. Medium white head. Lacy. Smells sour but somewhat similar to the lambic from the same year (I am also drinking it right now). ARoma is also nice citrus fruit of lemon. Head starts to disappear at the end. hits my mouth puckering but then balanced out perfectly by the sweet apricot. Wet finish also balances out the dry sour start. Finish is super long and leaves a balanced sour/touch of sweet. I get a lot of lemon through finish as well. Touches of light light caramel come through early. Really really a gem.

Big pour (it shouldve been for $12!) into a chalice at Brasserie V - Pours hazy light amber with a thin ring of white head. Smell is sour as hell and really acidic, but with a light, gentle apricot/peach note.Taste starts sour and fruity, then slowly builds into more and more tartness. Wow. The interplay between the intense sour and the gentle fruit is really something. Light and slick, with carbonation that sticks on your teeth. I felt like I lost a lot of enamel drinking this one, but it also blew me away.

Bottle via trade. (2010) Shared on my birthday with friends.  Pours a hazy orange with frothy head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma is heavy on the funk/sour with some lemon, peach and very noticeable apricot.  The taste is apricot at the front with then a great deal of lactic acid sour with some lemon and finally more apricot at the finish. Overall, an excellent sour.  This is my favorite Cantillon to date with great fruit and sour.  Will try to seek this out in the future with a more age on it to compare.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Light yellow opaque body. Overwhelming peach aroma. Taste is massively sour and fruity. Aftertaste mellows the sourness a bit and gives way to mild earthy tones and some wood.

Tasted on 8/14/11 from a 750mL capped and corked bottle obtained in a trade, bottled on August 25, 2008.  Pours a super cloudy orange with a thick orange tinted head that slowly recedes to thin spotty lace with a decent collar.  The nose is super sour, funky, and fruity with tons of lemon acidity, pitted fruits, a lactic creamy aroma, and some oaky vanilla as well.  The flavor is aggressively acidic and lactic with tons of lemon, pitted fruits that range from very ripe and juicy to under-ripe and green, and a nicely balancing vanilla oak flavor as well.  The body is light, but tannic, with light carbonation and a super long funky, fruity, and massively acidic finish.

On Tap!  Hazy apricot colored pour, plenty of carbonation and a very tart slightly sour aroma.  Flavor initially started off citrusy sour/tart a little funky, then as the beer had some time to warm up the apricot really started to shine through and really highlight the fruit.  Extremely well done, thanks again to the brewers at Cantillon!

Huge thanks to Deuane for busting this one out. I have been looking to try another one of these for a little while now. 2009 bottle.

A - Pours murky light orange with a big two finger tall white head leaving spotty lacing down the glass.
S - Smells of lots of sourness, sharp apricot and even some peach, light funk, and some dry oak tannins. I would have preferred just a bit more fruit but it isnt a huge deal really.
T - Starts off with a big dose of tart sourness slowly giving way to a mix of ripe apricot, damp must, and some dry oak tannins. The sourness is strong but once it dies down a bit you can detect the great fruit core of this beer. The finish is a mix of sourness and light dryness, lingering for some time.
M - Medium-Light body and flavor with moderate carbonation. It is very tart and dry in the feel lingering long after the finish. While the sourness is strong it straddles the line of being overpowering very well.
O - Easily one of the best sours out there. The sourness is strong but if you can get by it you are in for a treat. The fruit is a perfect complement to all that funky goodness. I cant wait to have this on-tap in a few days.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 2005 Vintage
Very sour and displayed lots of lime and apple maps. Undertones you find some peach. Still, quite a good beer, should be tried atleast once.

2011 Vintage
Holy shit! This is an apricot bomb with the puckering sourness that I love. This is probably the best beer Ive had from Cantillon.
750 ml bottle a hazy yellow colored beer with a white head aroma sourness apricot peach some sweetness flavor sourness apricot peach white fruits and a sourness finish

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar.
Pours golden with a white head.
Tart, dry and some petrol in the aroma.
Refreshing  taste of tart lemmon and grapefruit. Alot like Fanta Lemon.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2012 Rerated a fresh one @ ZZT V. C: Yellow colour. S: Abricot and peaches, mint, pretty nice and very fruity. T: Very sour with abricot notes. P: Sour, but balanced nicely.

Vintage 2010 Fou Foune

A - this lambic was poured into a snifter glass that I drink pretty much every one of my classy beers from. The appearance of this beer was exquisite. It looked exactly like the inside of an apricot (maybe a tinge lighter than the real fruit). Not much head to speak of on this beer (1/8 of a finger of head). Some carbonation beads trailing up the sides of the beer. 

S - you can smell that cellar funk that is common with many Cantillon brews. Really the smell of this lambic was the only thing that didnt impress me. There was a faint apricot smell to the beer and some sweet notes as well. 

T - a very impressive taste to this beer. You can really taste the apricot in the beer. There is some sweetness in the beer, but nothing that is overpowering. Upfront, there is that cellar funk that comes from the wild yeast., but that quickly disappears. What you are left with is a strong apricot essence with an accompanying pleasing sweetness. 

M - there is some carbonation in this beer, but nothing that is overpowering. As you swish it around your mouth, it feels very smooth and not at all watery. You can really tell that they have packed a lot into this beer. 

O - what can I say? My introduction to Cantillon brews was a success. I use to think (in my younger days) that Lindemans was the essence of what a lambic should be. I realized later that beers should pull their greatness from natural ingredients and not added sugar. Cantillon really shows that natural ingredients can come together to make a beer that really puts the fruit it was aged with in the forefront.

Aroma: fruits, wild, yeasts
Appearance: pale orange
Taste: well balanced, sour, fruity
Palate: medium body
OVERALL: 19/20

Bottle:
Small white head/lacing on top of a hazy orange colored beer.
Smell a fine mix of abricot, yeast and a bit sour.
Taste is a perfectly balanced mix of sour, abricot, some malts, light citric, hay, yeast and some barnyard notes.
Nice sour abricot aftertaste.
Low carbo, citricy mouthfeel, full body and a citric watery texture.
Lovely balanced, lovely beer!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: AUG 16, 2015 Secobd re-rate August 16th 2015. 2011 bottle @ home. Clear orange golden color, small white head. Aroma is soft and delicate balanced fruityness, peach and apricot. Taste is sour, sour yellow fruits, fruitpeel sour-bitter. Suitable body and carbonation. 10-4-8-4-18 this time. -- Re-rate @ ZZT V October 6th 2012: hazy orange color, small white lacing. Smell is lovely balanced peach and apricot, slightly sour. Taste has an absolutely fantastic balance. Again lightly sourish, apricot and fruityness. Lovely mouthfeel. 9-3-9-4-18=4.3. -- (Original rating: 8-3-7-3-14=3.5. Hazy yellow, head disappearing fast. Smell peach and abricot. Incredibly sour, but so very balanced! Very dry aftertaste. Carbo low to medium, body ok.)

Pours clear pale yellow with a large white head. The aroma is dry, funky and tart. Very Cantillon. Not as much apricot as I expected. Its there, but combined with lemon, leather and basement funk. The flavor is very lemony and tart with a delicate mouthfeel and some apricots near the finish with nice bretty funk. Dry, crisp and refreshing with a very light body.
3/10 i mörkhet. Frisk, syrlig och citrusaktig i lukten. Extremt syrlig och frisk i smaken. Syrlig och frisk eftersmak.

Backlog - May 13, 2010. 750ml bottle shared by blankboy with me and garthicus. Murky orange with a huge lasting fluffy off-white head.  Mmmmm - funky and pungent aroma, of course - lemon juice yet an almost equal heavily sweet component at war with it - sweet cherry? - wool, dry yeast ... I guess thats apricot, but how would I know, I dont like apricots - this smells great though.  The taste - holy crap thats good - a blast of lemon, dry oak resin, marmelade sweetness, raw wool funk in the background, as well as tons of dry floral bitterness - yummy.  Average body, frothy mouthfeel, medium to full-on acidity, solid carbonation, and a long dry sour tingly finish - awesome, enormously drinkable and I will buy one to drink in my hotel room when I visit London next.

On tap at Farmers Cabinet during the infamous mussels and frites brunch that was delicious going in and brutal coming out (damn shellfish allergies). Pours a full and hazy straw color with standard white head. Aroma is full of roses, lemon, raspberry, and a touch of barnyard. Flavor is delicate and delightfully tart: notes of apricot, lemon, and strawberry. Moderate acidity with a bubbly champagne feel. Its plenty tart but at the same time light and ridiculously clean. Wonderful deliciousness.
Pours gold with a thin white head.  Smells acidic and funky.  Taste is overwhelming acidic and dry, almost like drinking battery acid.  Not my thing.

Medium white head. Hazy opaque yellow body. Intense wooden lemony barnyard aroma with wheaty floral notes. Dry-acidic wheaty mealy floral taste with vinegary spicy lemon notes. Mid-bodied. Faintly sharpish mouthfeel. Dry-acidic wheaty apple and vinegar aftertaste. Lovely. Balanced and easy to drink. (0.2l draft at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen.)

Big thanks to Ryan for pulling this out of his cellar to share. What a treat this was. A perfect score for me. What else can I say. The aroma, the flavor, the appearance was just stellar. Everything screamed apricot and tart flavors. Would love to try this one again. I cant remember what vintage though, possibly 2007.

75cl Bottle, thanks NoiZe! Hazy golden yellow colour, white head. Aroma of apricot, peach, lemon, funk, typical Cantillon (as referred to what Ive had so far from Cantillon) which is really nice. Flavour is some apricot upfront, quickly taken over by a potent sourness, lots of lemon, wheat, hint of leather, later on becomes more fruity, apricot and peach. Light bodied. Nice enough.

750ml bottled August 2010. Beginning of the bottle is a clear golden yellow, becomes much cloudier/completely opaque, more orange, both with an off-white head. Apricot, some farmhouse, sweet, and very delicate. Surprisingly sour compared to the aroma but not overwhelming, some sweetness and a tang from the apricot, nice dry finish. Supremely well balanced - great delicate lambic.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2012 Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Vintage 2005. Clear light orange with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, heavy apricot and moderate acidic. Flavor is medium sweet, rather sour and rather acidic. Bone dry and rather acidic finish. 270112. 8/3/8/4/17=4.0 --- Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Vintage 2011. Clear light orange with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and apricot. Flavor is rather sweet, moderate sour and rather acidic. Rather dry and moderate acidic finish. 270112. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9 --- Earlier rating: Cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma is moderate sour, fruity and yeasty. Flavor is light sweet, rather sour and very acidic. Bone dry and acidic finish. 260511. 8/4/8/4/16=4.0

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ bar. Pours cloudy golden. Aroma is honey, sweet, fruity and sour; all well mated together. So good fresh, fruity, sour and bitter flavor. Finishes balanced sour acidy, fruity and tart.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar. Pours unclear straw yellow with a nice white head. Aroma has sharp barnyard, funk, classic Cantillon, then a nice touch of peach that gives some nice sweetness which balances out nicely. Smells exactly like Haribo Ferskner candy. Taste is tart, dry brett, leather and barnyard, but the tartness is really well rounded by the fruity peach that again gives some sweetness. Funk and some peach in the finish. Nice balance all over.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2012 Draught at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen cons 2011-05-27
AR: tart yeast, apricots, a bit nutty
AP: hazy apricots juice
F: apricots, sourness yeeeeesssss

Retade: bottle from Ölbuttiken vintage 2005 cons 2012-09-01 Göteborg
AR: tartness,dusty, 
AP: hazy apricot juice, golden head
F: bitter, bitter, bitter, yeasty, grapes, grape fruit concentrate, after all the bitterness there is à apricot puré that is lovely
But this one should be drinken fresh!!! New rating 4,3...

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2014 Re-Rate .. Thanks to Phredrik for sharing a bottle from 2005. Pours hazy dark yellow with a small white head. Aroma has lots of apricot, sour berries, tart, gentle funky brett, and a touch of stable and leather. Taste has sour green apples, lots of nice apricot, sour berries, brett, weak barnyardy notes, very tart and some peachy kinda sweet citrus notes. Very nice palate and a very good balance.. Love this! Re - rating this biatch. Pours hazy orange with a white head. Very funky and apricot forward aroma. Also some "haribo ferskner", Apricot yogurt and just a great balance between the funk and the fruitiness. Taste is quite the same with a delicious body. Apricot, peach notes, lacto, barnyard, vinegar, sweet , lacto acid and once again a nice balance between the funk and the fruitiness! AWESOME BEER!

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2014 Draught at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Pale yellow, small head. Apple aroma, berries, rubber, sourish, vinous, citrus and maybe some apricot. Citrus flavor, grapefruit, vinous, rubber, apple notes. Very refreshing and drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Draught at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen, Denmark. Hazy golden, no head. Fresh tart tropical fruit aroma, with apricot notes. Light to medium bodied. Dry with strong acidity, but feels more accessible than ordinary Cantillons. Very refreshing.

Bottle at Maltzillas tasting shared by HonusWagner (I think). 2005 vintage. Pours hazy brownish yellow color with white head. Slightly fruity aroma with some sourness. Flavor is total sourness, not really getting any apricot. Light to medium body with moderate carbonation. Thanks Mike.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 2005 bottle thanks to Ryan Witter!

Unfortunately, this fulfills my concerns about fruit lambics and aging them; the beer lacks any discernible apricot flavor or aroma and just ends up tasting like unblended, extremely sour and lactic lambic.  Still really good, but not as tasty as the fresh samples Ive had.

2010 375ml Japanese edition bottle shared with Weisguy & lamplighter for one of our small weekly tastings.
Served slightly chilled, a huge head appeared on a fast pour decanted into one glass to share between the three of us. Hard to tell how much sediment was left, but I would guess 1-2 ounces. Color was a light yellow with a gold hue up to the light with a couple tiny bits of sediment swimming around. Smell was sharp fruit and some vinegar. Described by Ari as "smelling a peach pit." Notes of peach and apricot skin were very evident. The taste was an intense combination of resiny sour apricot and fruity acidity, while much funk was almost nowhere to be found. Unnoticeable alcohol on the palate and finish, but a slight burn from the acidity was present. Mouthfeel was medium bodied and Im sure it would have been a cinch for any of us to drink over a liter of this. Ive had Foufoune a few times (many courtesy of Weisguy), including a fresh 750 of the 2010 bottling, but this bottle stood out as nearly a whole nother beer than what I tasted before. Much more fruit on the nose and tongue, while the balanced acidity made for a very enjoyable lambic.

My first lambic scoring. Got it at ølbutikkens reopening and bought a Bottle. Golden hazy brown. Citrus apricote rose aroma. Very well balance between the heavy sour taste and the bitterness. Long pleasant finish. This could be the start of a sour brew era.

Rating #532, draught at Ølbutikken at their re-opening  

A completely yellow opaque beer and a high good lasting head. Aroma is orange, mandarine, apricot, sourishness, yeast and some indefinite spices. Very sour taste, though with some sweetness recognizeable, very fresh and makes your mouth water come forward. Orange, yeast and spices are repeating from the aroma, and theres some wood as well now. Fine bitterness in the finish. Medium body. A very sour but as well very well tasting lambic.

(750ml bottle 2010 vintage) hazy golden orange pour with sparse medium sized soapy white bubbles. Nose of wet wood, a bit of woody char, tart tangerine, mild tobacco, apricot, honey, peach, and a slight earthiness. Taste of tart fruit, peach, apricot (dried), wet wood, mild wood char, delicious tart earthiness reminiscent of currant, and slight saltiness. Chewable vitamins as it warms.  Great tart linger with very long linger. A very well balanced sour that never forgets not to be acidic. Easy to drink. Id love to try it again!
smells true to its fruit.  delicious ripe apricots, orange blossom honey, and maybe mint leaves. fruity and tarty. much like freddie mercury. just without the mustache.

Another Cantillon, so much fun. 2007 vintage. Beer is yellow and hazy. Forms a white head and true to the brewery leaves no lacing behind, thats fine.

Aroma is super sour, really tart. Smells awesome.

Slight sulfur, tastes kind of like flowers. Im not picking up on the fruit so much. Its pretty sour. I think it smells better than it tastes. Overall drinkability is good and mouthfeel is good as well.

Serving type: bottle

750ml bottle, 2008 version...The beer pours dark peacy with a much darker center. The head is white, rises about a finger and is gone pretty quickly...The aroma is on the lighter side, light tart fruits, mixed with sourness. Not overpowering in either regard so its balanced giving some of what you look for in a fruit lambic...Holy moses, thats one sour beer. Didnt think it would be that tart from the aroma. Its got a huge tart bite sour, not a mucky horse blanker leather like a lot of Cantillons. Here you get a lot more of the fruit not sweetness but the actual taste of apricots on the finish. Super balanced and flavorful...The feel is great, sticks to the mouth, very tannic...Drinkability is off the charts. It gives me everything I love about a lambic, sourness funk, but balanced enough that you can drink this all day, while at the same time not being such a fruit beer thats its super sweet or dominated by the apricot...Overall one of my favorite lambics, right up there with Blabear.

Draught at The Trappist. Hazy orange with a medium white head. Dusty sour aroma with a good deal of sour fruit. Hint of dried apricot sweetness and a moderately sour finish. Very clean overall. Not intensely sour, but well-balanced and refreshing. Very good, as you would expect from cantillon, but I would have liked a little more fruit and even a little more acidity. Ive heard stories of this one being intensely sour, but this blend is certainly not up that alley.

750 ml green bottle. Bottled August 11, 2010. Consumed March 16, 2011.  A hazy golden beer with a nice fluffy head. The aroma is very nice, tart and sour with lots of lemons and some green apples. Very fruity but not overpowering.Some funk in there also. Wow. The taste again is tart on the lips with the apricots showing themselves in the end. Very lemony with the oak showing itself also. The funk also makes a presence with the rest.This really makes me lick my lips which I like.

All these things that  speak of seem to work in harmony with each other and not overtake one another. This is really light and delicate, very refreshing. Very balanced also. I shared a glass with my brother whose beer of choice is Bud Light Lime and he really enjoyed it. Here is to hoping this great fruited sour converts someone from the dark side.
Bottle. Color orange with big head. Aroma sweet, sour, apricot.Taste sour, apricot, peach, lemon.

Tap @ Moeder Lambic.
Dorée avec une légère brume, mousse épaisse blanche.
Arôme fruité dont on ressent bien labricot fermenté.
Ce nez garde ce côté agréable de cave avec une fine aigreur et notes de levures sauvages.
En bouche, un palais qui est sec, fruité allant de la citronnelle à labricot le tout en conservant ces relents de lambic/orge. Une effervescence en bouche qui est agréable avec une bonne dose des abricots tout en gardant ce profile bien lambic. A noter aussi le chêne et une fine acidité lactique au fini.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 Rerate November 2016: 2016 vintage, 75cl bottle picked up at the brewery. It pours a mostly clean bright apricot color with a minimal white head. Aroma is full of tangy citric notes, light musty basement funk, stone fruit, apricot marmalade. Taste is initially citric, acidic, softly sweet and fruity with a mostly indefinite stone fruit note, light passion fruit, more funky basement and lemon juice. The bottom of the bottle is hazy and juicy with loads more acidity and clean concentrate apricot jam notes, only slightly muddled by the earthy yeast tones. As the beer warms up, also the initial pours start to show more apricots, jammy pulpy fruits and a little more funk. I think this years batch is at it sweet spot for fruitiness right now, having cleaned the "green" bitter notes it had initially 2 months ago. Letting it sit will open up more funk and tartness, also looking forward to that. Score: 4.5
Rerate September 2016: 2016 vintage drank super fresh at Zwanze 2016, Kernel, London. It pours a hazed apricot color with a small white head. Aroma is tangy fruity acidic with lemon peel and light peachy jammy fruits. Taste is also tart acidic and lightly fruity jammy peachy with notes of stone fruits and lemon peel. A closing bitterness ruins the long acidic finish accompanied by jammy apricots notes which Ive come to love in this beer. Overall, feels too "green" and fresh, hopefully will improve with time. Score 3.8
Rerate September 2015: 2015 vintage extra fresh at Zwanze Day. This was my beer of the night hands down. Super smooth, plenty of apricots in both the nose ad the taste. Clean lemony sourness but never too acidic. Amazing Cantillon lambic with unique apricots twist, might just be my favourite beer. Score 4.5
Rerate August 2012: 2012 vintage, drank in 2012, was much less harsh on the acidic side. The nose and taste were much more rounded with apricot sweetness, but it lacked the final apricot-concentrate like kick that I thoroughly enjoyed in my 2007 vintage. Good fresh for sure, but I think I preferred the aged version. Score 4.0
Original rate from 2011: 75cl bottle. 2007 vintage. Pours a cloudy orangish color with a big fizzy white head. Aroma is mostly sweet-sour with oak and horse blanket qualities. As it warms up, apricots become more present and the residuals  on the bottom of the bottle are pure apricots juice. Taste is sweet/sour, almost lemon peel. Grassy earthy notes. Fruity sweetness is subtle but definitely perceivable if compared to regular Cantillons lambics and certainly helps to balance a bit the flavors. Medium bodied and lots of carbonation.Very refreshing but at same time complex brew. Stunning. Score 4.2

Thanks to Shawn for a chance at tasting this beauty!

Hazy golden straw in color, decent amount of crisp white head with a decent amount of retention. It sticks around in small trellice on the edges.

Smells sweet and fruity (apricot, peach) with a little bit of barnyard funk/straw and just a hint of acidic sourness.

Taste is mellow and smooth up front but builds to a nice sour tartness with a slight acidity in the middle of the taste. The finish has barnyard funk and a fruity apricot flavor. Very nice balance in here, nothing overpowers. The sourness is subtle, the funk is subtle, and the apricot is subtle. This creates just a beautifully balanced, easy drinking, lambic.

The body is more on the thin side, really slight carbonation which is perfect for style. I wouldnt want a change to this. Crisp and refreshing with only a tinge of acidic bite

This beer would be awesome with a plain vanilla cheesecake or panna cotta. Something sweet but not strongly flavored. A soft cows milk cheese such as manchego.

On tap at Hill Farmstead Winter Festival.

Big, puffy, foamy, white head. Hazy, straw color. Laces glass the entire drinking experience.

A - Apricot is immediately evident, but subtle and pleasant. Expected funk mixes wonderfully with must and just a touch of bite.

T - Pleasantly tart apricots and fresh bitterness on the finish. Wonderfully balanced blend of funk and sharpness.

M - Just the right amount of body that balances with good carbonation and  sourness. 

D- Entirely too drinkable, frankly. Truly excellent.

Serving type: on-tap

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2012 old rating. Sweet and fruity nose with peaches and honey, some yogurt and cheese, but the funk is rather clean. Taste is moderately sweet, moderately sour, some solid lactic acids, a touch of acetic, lots of peach and apricot, some golden raisins and hay. Lemon rind finish. Medium body is very soft with light carbonation.

75 cl bottle that says L12/06 and "expires" 2009, pours a light orange with a minor white head, aroma is pretty tart with notes of barnyard, wood, lemon and very subtle apricot, taste is pretty much the same and again the fruit is very subdued/subtle at this point, but thats perfectly natural, it is still very nice lambic overall no doubt.

2005 vintage. Murky deep yellow with a small white head. Medium sour and funky, with a slight fruitiness, though not really apricots (as expected due to the age). More like a gueuze, and a good one at that. Cheekdrying but still kind of mild and smooth drinking, yet with attitude.

Thanks to Matt. Pours a beautiful golden orange with a big dense white head. The aroma is all apricot with a hint of citrus hops and some spice. This beer was more fruit than sour. Cantillon continues to fuse lambics with non typical fruits. Awesome beer.

2003- Drinking about right now. Still alot of funk and sour, but the mouth is really smoothing out. The apricots are huge in the mouth. Cheese and egg for some reason hits you. Wow. Very strange and wonderful.  Cantillon can go forever.

750 ml bottle at Dereks Tasting. Awesome! Pours a hazy straw golden hue, a bit dulled, yellowed with a nice big bright white head that dies to a clinging to the corners head, laces ok. Aromas are apricots, peach, tart lemons, lactic acid, straw and hay, touches of funky brett, dry to the bone.  Initial is dry and tart, fairly light bodied with big tart apricots, lemons, tart lactic acid dances on the palate with hay, straw, touches of funk, bready malts. Tartness and sourness grows on the palate, peaches and apricots provide sour and light sweetness, rich lactic acid, funky bread, some bready malts. Tart lemons.. Sour apricots. Lactic, nice funk. Sour, but balanced, good carbonation. Very tasty. Mmmmmm

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2016 2010 Bottle shared by Kyle, thanks! Pours a clear golden peach with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has lots of apricot throughout with a hint of backing funk and sourness. Flavor starts with really fresh apricot with a decent amount of funk and a good amount of acid.

Bottle shared by Shane, thanks! Poured a hazy pale yellow with a white head that started and finished at the edges. Aroma is a great combination of sour apricot (nearly acidic) and a barnyard funk. Flavor started with apricot that grew in sourness throughout to acidity. There was a nice backing funk that had a barnyard note to it.
Draft @ Blind Tiger. Golden orange pour with white head. Tart apricot, funky aroma. Flavor is acidic, citrus, apricot, sour fruit, oak notes. Very nice.
13th January 2008  Typically sharp and dry but not enough to induce puckering! Apricot is subtle but there. The finish is more sour.
Theres some notes that I cant read. I really should start to make readable notes.

Have had 2 of these.  First was a 2001 bottle, second was a 2009 bottle.  The 2001 was still amazingly sour.  2009 had much more apricot and a lot less sour.  Both would be categorized as a couple of the best beers I have ever had, but the 2001 was worth it.

Bottle from notes. Pours a golden straw with dense white head. Aromas of acidic sourness and some light stone fruit in the background. Apricots are not as dominant as expected. Flavours of acoidic sourness. Nice beer but not my favourite cantillon.

Bottled 08/8/2010. Consumed 12/15/2010. 

Pours paler than I imagined. Fou Foune is not cloudy, but shes certainly not transparent either. The color is a slightly muted Dandelion; Jonquil is probably the best descriptor available. Even at first pour, theres a nice half finger head that settles into a frothy ring.  

The nose excites and is certainly more fruit-forward than I remember. Sweet apricots, fresh, sugared peaches, a managed citrus acidity, and some floral notes. Almost no funk whatsoever. 

Muted apricots, citrus, and the pits of prunus fruits, which I think is a result of the oak acting on the fruits: peach, apricot, almonds. Not overly acidic, but it has some citric and lactic acid bite to it. Im not sure if malic acid is here, but I pick up on that fresh, green apple tartness characteristic of it. Nice ascescence without the accompanying astringency found in some sour beers; its almost puckering, but without tannin presence. Theres some minor chalkiness that provides body mid-palate. 

Quite light and refreshing, as expected. Just under medium carbonation. Dry throughout the palate.

Apricot comes through strongly in the nose, but even now, at a few months, the taste is mostly comprised by citric and malic acidity reminiscent of lemons/green apple. Its oaky and its dryness brings out the fruit-pit flavors sometimes caused by brett, but I get little funkiness.

Thanks Bill.  2007 vintage purchased at Cantillon.  The beer pours to a thin plastic looking light straw body with a white head.  The aroma is really sour apricots with some funky gueuze components.  The flavor is extremely sour apricots and funk.  Super sour palate.  This is a PH1 kind of beer for me.

On tap at Capones.

A: Pours a pale apricot with a nice white head. A bit of lacing and a minimal head that stays throughout.

S: Very, very sour with lots of apricot and white peach notes. A bit of funk and oak.

T: Loads of apricot with some very nice lactic sourness. A bit of funk, earth, and wood; mainly, though, this one is all about the sour apricot and I love it.

M: Fairly light bodied and incredibly dry and crisp. Very powerful acidity.

D: Very nice drinkability, although anything over 10oz. or so might get to be a little much. Overall, absolutely fantastic. In my opinion, blew Saint Lamvinus (which we had side-by-side) out of the water.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 02-17-2010

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2014 Rerate oktober 2014: stor trevlig och syrlig doft av härlig aprikos. Smaken är underbar syrlig med en härlig balans. Så len och fin.

2010:

Flaskan var från 2005, fanns knappt någon fruktighet kvar. Syrlig, källare, citrus, gräs och något som påminde lätt om "bensin". God men jag vill prova en färskare nästa gång.

Thanks CanIHave4Beers! 750mL. Dated 13 Aug 09.. Brilliant orange gold. Lots of apricot in the nose, no complaiints here. Flavor is very intense, very sour. Lots of apricot. High carbonation. Definitely a nostril stinger. Nice funk. Lilac.
Floral peach-apricot, slightly sweet aroma.  Pours hazy golden with with a nice white head.  Mild tartness with that peach-apricot flavor, quite acidic.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2011 Bottle courtesy of Diego shared at the Ryans tasting.  Achie machie!!!!!  Big barnyard and horse blanket nose.  This is one sour/bitter beer.  Super dry and crisp, it was so sour I could barley pick out any flavors, I guess apricot?
Update: 05 vintage was suffering from autolysis and had a huge burnt rubber nose..

Pours a golden orange honestly it is the color of an apricot. The beer has a big head that leaves some lace. The aroma is lots of barn-yardiness, but with a lot of apricot fruitiness in there as well with some both clean and dirty laundry. The flavor smacks you in the face right away with apricot, fresh, delicious apricots. The beer is very very sour. Its also really dry with a dryness akin to say a brut. The fruitiness continues with some lemon rind earthy on sour notes. Dominantly this beer is packed with sourness and apricot flavor. The palate is fizzy but remarkably full and easy to drink. Just one damn fine beer.

Bottle. 2008 vintage. Pours a slightly hazed orange amber color with a slight white head that collars around the glass. The aroma is awesome with definite ntoes of apricot along with some acidity and funkiness. Light mouthfeel with some good carbonation. The taste is really nice with a balance of fruit notes (apricot, grapefruit) and sour acidity. This one does leaves you puckering a bit but not overly so. Overall, a really good beer and one I am glad I got to try.

2007 vintage purchased 5/2008
Straw colored pour w/ a whispy small white head slightly cloudy.
Funky hints of hay, definatelly sour then some more sour... theres a tiny hint of fruit, but its just  a subtle note.  Nice even tongue punching palate.  Hugely sour beer, more a sour than a fruit.  Nice puckering cheek feel.  A lighty funky hay touch w/ some tiny touch of fruits.  Aggressively carbonated.. nicely complex definate hints of the barnyard and a touch of leather.
Oddly nice beer, the age did it well.

Green bottle, 75 cl, bottled in 2009, best before 12/2018, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on October 9 2010; eye: peach, hazy, nice effervescence, tiny sheet of creamy white head, no lacing; nose: sourness, green apple, basement, farm, horse; mouth: sourness, green apple, basement, farm, horse, oxidation, sour finale, medium body, good carbonation, slick texture; overall: not for me

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 75 cl, embouteillée en 2009, meilleure avant 12/2018, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 9 octobre 2010; il : pêche, trouble, bonne effervescence, petite couverture de mousse crémeuse blanche, pas de dentelle; nez : aigre, pomme verte, cave, ferme, cheval, bouche : aigre, pomme verte, cave, ferme, cheval, oxydation, finale aigre, corps moyen, bonne carbonatation, texture coulante; en résumé : pas pour moi

Bottle, tfs Vaiz! Yellowish pour. Aroma is brett, lots of fruit and presumably cookies. (Damn, even I cant read my own handwriting.)
Flavour is deep sour brett, in a very smooth way, some butter and apricot.
Lingering for ages. Nice one.

Bottle opened just after the Emelisse oktoberfest had finished. Fruity fresh aroma with loads of brett. Flavor is very sour and fruity but still smooth and soft. Mostly sour in the finish and just after that. Very nice brew.

2007 Bottle.  Charming appearance with a pale, slightly hazy, light yellow-gold color and a thin, very fine white head.  Sharply sour aroma that comes across acetic at first, then softens slightly to reveal bright apricot notes.  The apricot elements are combined with sour fermentation and creates an unusual under ripe apricot note.  Additional light herbaceousness, soft lemon, stonefruit pits, and sweet nectar are also present.  The flavor is sharply tart with stonefruit notes, barrel-aged oxidation, and a faint spiciness.  The body is light but mouth-wateringly sour with ample carbonation that provides a deft, nimble mouthfeel that is very refreshing. Excellent.

Bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass very zippy, nice head. Starts very sour, quite fruity like lemon. Only small hints of apricot in the background. Finish aggressiv sour. Interesting, but not my favourite!

Tap at Spuyten Duyvil. No vintage reported. Poured a glowing, full hazy, bright orange with powerful carbonation and a thin but persistent white head leaves swathes of lace. Nose is amazing geuze character: bright citrus, lemons, tropical melons, sweat, salt water. Taste is full sour with amazing fresh fruit character though one specific fruit is impossible to pinpoint. "Apricot" is not necessarily evident as much as some medley of tropical melons and tangerines. Some slight eggy suplhur character comes in and out but does not detract too much from what is a massive lactic body that is zippy on the palate. Very refreshing, very sour. Cant wait to crack some vintage bottles.

2005 Vintage - thanks to Jason for this one. Pours a hazy orange color with a nice white head and good lacing. Wow. Nicely tart....supple apricots & funky aroma. Tingly, somewhat sticky texture and palate cleansing mouthfeel. The aging has been kind to the flavors, though the apricots were present, buried deep and soft. Still big and funky with a dry / sweet finish. Yummy stuff. Excited that Jean will be brewing more of this outstanding lambic.

Out of a barrel @ Cantillon brewery as a special surprise, free of charge. Apparently, our big smiles, enthusiasm and interest in the brewery, the family and their products got us this one. My first apricot lambic, this one pours a slightly hazy light orange body, completely flat as oude lambics should be. Aroma is fairly mild, with only apricot and wine yeast surfacing from the glass. Taste is much nicer, with a sour tartiness coming in first and a sweeter, floral apricot tone intervening towards the end. A very smooth creation, and an interesting and fascinating special treat from the people at Cantillon - just before closing time! :-)

2010 On tap at Moeder Lambic in Brussels. Pours a huge white head and a cloudy orange hue. The aroma is massive and very aggressive apricots, no hint of sourness. The flavor is very dry and tart with again huge apricots providing lots of sweetness and juice. Very damn good.

(750 ml bottle @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. Rated @ 4.6.2010.)
Orange colour with a nice off-white head which leaves a good-looking lacing on the glass. The nose is apricot sour, lemonish and yeasty. Really sour taste where the apricots finally kick in with their acidity. Light bodied and nicely carbonated. Could be a bit more balanced though.

75cl bottle at home, vintage 2005 shared with oj83. Once again thanks to Anker for this! This was a very sour lambic, burn the back of the throat sour. I found it to be just too intense for my liking, there was no balance unlike the fantastic blabaer we had before. The taste was apricot backed up by huge sourness. There was little funk and complexity. I love cantillon but this one was not for me.

Flaske: Flot hvedefarvet uklar øl med et tæt flot skumhoved. Kraftig duft af stald og geuze men nærmest ingen abrikos.
