Sampled at BDRs tasting and shared by BDR. Pours a hazy golden blonde brew with a thin fizzy white head that quickly dissipates to a film top. Aroma of barnyard funk, tart apricots, peach and some lemon zest. Taste is medium bodied, lots of carbonation, sour (naturally) with flavors of tart soft fruits, peach character, yeast, and some herbs. Finish remains tart that lasts a while after the finish.
(Bottle at Kaisla on 2008-02-16) Hazy and golden. Rather big head. Sourness and fruitiness in nose. Sour taste with apricots in aftertaste. Very good.

Hazy golden beer with a small white head. Sour and fruity aroma. Dried apricots are hardly noticable. The same goes for the flavor: sour, fruity (citrus) and a dry sour finish. Apricots are agian hardly noticable.

2006 bottle from Hopduvel, Gent. Murky, opaque gold colour with no head yet plenty of carbonation. Musty, almost vinegary aroma of mushrooms, dried apricots and orange peel. Flavour was very astringent, with some more fruit, yeast and a very dry, sour finish. Not my favourite Cantillon beer by a long way.

Thanks to BDR for sharing.  2002 vintage bottle, pours a cloudy, yellow-orange body with white head.  Funky aroma with sour citrus character.  Incredibly sour fruit flavor makes this a difficult beer to drink.  Once you get used to it a bit, the apricot, lemon, and peach flavors start to come out a bit.  Medium bodied, mouth-puckering mouthfeel.  Acidy, citrus finish.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 [Bottle--02, thanks for sharing, BDR!] Pours very murky golden with a small white head. Aroma is very funky and sour with almost no fruit detectable. The taste is once again quite funky, and extremely sour--one of the most sour beers that I have ever tasted. This is then followed by a blast of apricot that really makes the beer. Medium mouthfeel with a fairly long, fruity finish. The smell was fairly average, but this was still an enjoyable lambic. Old rating: 6/3/8/4/16 = 3.7Re-rate: [Bottle, 04] I believe that thanks go to Levi for sharing this bottle. Really outstanding, and one of the highlights of an already great tasting. Still one of the sourest beers that I have tried, but I really appreciated the integration with the fruit. Overall, one of my favorite fruit lambics for sure, and Ill give a hefty bump in score to reflect that.
Thanks to BDR for sharing.  Cloudy yellow/gold.  Some carbonation.  Sour aroma with apricot.  Flavor is very sour, even for a Cantillon.  Excellent.  Full bodied, extremely flavorful and very sour.

Ratting 1800.  Thanks me!!!  2002 vintage.  Beautiful cloudy peach colored body.  Huge barnyard funk on the nose - faint lactic character as well.  Complex body with apricots blending in and out of a perfectly brett overridden bottle.  Amazingly tart finish.  Outstanding.

37,5cl. 06 bottling. Hazy, light golden yellow with fizzy and small white head. Softly tart aroma, strong fresh apricots. Flavor is dry apricots, sharp citric tartness. Fresh fruity finish. Yeast adds slight wheaty note, and smoothens everything. Medium bodied, strongly carbonated, slightly tannic and dry palate. A bit easier one.

750mL bottle 2002.  Cloudy orange yellow with a medium sized rocky white head.  Musty aroma, acetic and apricoty.  Tannic apricot with bretty horse flavors.  Sharp acidity with a residual fruit note.  Lingering apricot skin in the finish.  Mouthfeel is light, rather dry.

Bottle. Creamy off-white but very quickly disappearing head. Hazy orange body with lots of yeast sediments. Oranges grapefruit acidic aroma. Powerful vinegar grapefruit not just acidic but in fact sharp and sour fruity flavor with low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Re-rate 11/13: Bottle sample at a sour tasting at  the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. 2013 bottle. Cloudy yellow with a white head. Wonderful aroma full of apricots, barnyard and a bit of lemony notes. Sour and funky flavor with oak and some apricots. Medium-bodied, tingling carbonation. 9/4/8/4/16=4.1

(3/11/08) Bottle at Delirium Cafe in Brussels. Bottled in 2006. Slightly hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma of apricots, bretty funk and some citrus. Very dry sour flavor with some apricots and some lemon in the finish. Medium-bodied. Very good. 7/4/8/3/15=3.7

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2014 Bottle from Dranken Geers.  Hazy orange gold with disappearing head.  Yep, its got apricot on aroma, with some funk.  Pretty well carbonated.  Its an odd mix of sweet apricot fruit and a full on dry sharp lemony lambic.  The aroma is what?  Funk and sweet apricot.  Really acidic sharp finish.  Not sure that I like it that much.  Nice in mouthfeel with sharp stewed apple.  Very dry on end.  Well made, nothing wrong with it, but not for me. 2.6/5 previous rating was from when I was an idiot.  On tap at Borefts 2014.  Amazing love the fruit and sourness.  Just beautiful.

Clear golden body with a medium frothy white head. Yeasty aroma wtih apricot, fruit and lots of horseblanket. Very sour apricot flavor with fruit and some horseblanket. Very light body with moderately high carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 Ive tried this many times, generally with some years of aging.  Yeah...this is the bomb  Ive had many Cantillons and been to the brewery, and this apricot funky sour masterpiece and the Lou Pepe fruity concoctions rock  Cloudy copper-apricot.  Giant aroma of sour, funky apricot.  Taste is mouth puckering but delicious in the sour arena ... barnyard and horse blanket, acidic, apricot and other tart fruits with just enough sweetness to keep it intriguing.  Ages well.

bottled in 2004, drunk in march 2008.  pours a hazy cloudy straw honey color, with a thin white head that fades quickly.  oh my what a smell!  abundant sour apricot--dominating, but not overpowering--sour funky cantillon yeast, lemon zest, and a very light honey malt.  very light apricot taste, some lemon, some pale malt, but oh dear me thats sour!  some grapey notes kick in here and there as well, maybe some grass and some must and some vinegar.  finshes, guess what? sour!  light sweetness, id call it dry, but my mouth waters so much after that its hard to tell.  very acidic.  light body, with a great texture from the carbonation.  great stuff.  the apricots are there in just the right abundance, and theres a ton of acidity and sourness, but enough complexity to keep it from being one-dimensional.  i put a lot of money into it, but im quite glad i did.  the smell reminds me of the trolli gummy hamburger buns, if anyone knows what i mean.
Bottle 75 cl. Small white head, deep orange/yellow colour. Good looking. Nice aroma of apricots. The flavour is very acidic/sour but is some how balanced  by some sweetness in the finish.

Bottle, 75cl. Yesterday with William ...
Light hazy golden color, little white head. 
Aroma fruits, sourness, lambic. 
Medium body.
Taste sourness, malts, dry, milksour.
We can not taste the apricots.
Good beer.

Pours a hazy peach color with a white head.  Aroma is fruity, cheesy, funk, brett, and some oak.  Flavor is fruity, malty, funky, cheesy, with a dry fruity tart finish.  Another good beer from Cantillon but not my favorite.

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a moderate sized off-white head. Aroma is tart and lactic, with nice accent form the apricot. Flavor is very tart, making my lips pucker. Apricot is present only in the background. Long, dry, tart finish. Great Lambic.

beautiful sour acidity and sweet fruit.  Juicy apricot washes all over the tongue.  Strong sourness everywhere, but aided by a real sweetness balancing it.  Sweet at the initial sip.  Champagne like light effervescent palate.  Feels full in the mouth, but light and refeshing.  Another incredible summer beer, easy to drink and refreshing, but comlex and vary tasty.  Does have slight hints of Belgian barnyard funk, but it is hiding pretty well.  Just about as good as the style gets.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 750, bottled in 2004. Pours a crystal clear yellow hue, virtually no head. Aroma is most noticeably sour, with funk and apricot in the background. A little more funk in the flavor, but sour still dominates, the apricot really kicks in on the finish though and lasts awhile on the palate. Again, very sour, even for a Cantillon, but avoided anything vinegary. Solid brew. 7-4-8-4-14

6/7/08, on tap at Spuyten Duyvil. Aroma starts off almost cheese-like, then transforms to robust apricots upon warming. Flavor entirely tart apricots, almost hot/spicy tart. Not as overwhelmingly sour as from the bottle. 8-4-8-4-15
Poured a hazy light yellow color with small white head.  Tart citrus and horsey aroma.  Big acidic citrus and tart flavor.  Clean finish.  Yum yum.

2003.  a peach hued beer with a small white head.  extremely sour, brett, apricot aroma.  very sour with flavors of vinegar, apricot, brett.  i can feel it burning my stomach.  heartburn tonight!  probably the most sour beer ive tried.

Bottle.  Poured hazy yellow in color with a thin white head. Oh so wonderful aroma of Cantillon yeast and funk with a touch of sweet from the fruit.  Taste is jaw puckering excellence.  Flavors of barnyard, funk, slight apricot, but overall just a ton of sour and tart. I found this one more acidic then most other 
Cantillons, but it wasnt horrible.  Of all the Cantillons I have had this one tops the charts in tartness and I love it. I want more.
cloudy yellow coloured body with a white head a sour fruity ( abricot) aroma a ful sour pallet a sour fruity finich not my style off beer

Cloudy yellow colour with small white head. Strong sour aroma with a hint of sweet abricot. Full sour diminishing palate finishing off strong bitter and fruity. Its not the beer to drink all night long but just one is heavenly.
Hazy yellow coloured beer with a small white head. Very fruity sweet-sour aroma. Full sour palate. FInish is sour fruity with a dry tart finish. Very enjoyable lambic.

11/7/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is very sulfuric, sweet/sour with lots of fruit, mainly apricot, and earthy tones.  Appearance  is hazy light yellow with a low white head.  Flavor is earthy forward, with very tart fruit, low fruity sweetness, complex and clashing.  Mouthfeel is spritzy, medium bodied, and resiny in the finish.  Overall, this isnt terrible, but definitely lacks the smoothness or balance such a well reviewed beer should have.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2016 Bottle, bought @ YNWA, Kolding. Pours a hazy pale yellow without any head. Looks a bit like apple juice. Aroma is musky, apricot, barnyard and a slight fruity tartness. Low carbonation, giving the beer a slight oily feel. Flavour is powerfully tart at first, slight oakiness mixing well. Very dry mouthfeel, but it is stunningly well-crafted the way the fruity apricot flavours abound after the tartness has subdued. Very nice. (and stunning for a hot Chili Con Carne)
7/2/9/3/17 = 3.8
Re-rate: Tap @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Hazy golden with a lovely, white head. Sweetish aroma with a sh**-load of apricot and actually peach. Light carbonation, great dryness. Just top-class flavour, apricot, exoticness, tart, fruity and incredibly fresh. Just magnificent.
9/4/9/4/17 = 4.3

Second rerate. Magnificent Aroma of apricot, seriously tart. Wonderful. 
9/4/9/4/18 = 4.4

Bottled. Hazy orange colour, small white sparkling head. Aroma is concentrated sourness along with wood and fruits. Flavour is very much the same with some slight fruity notes lurking behind the sourness. Dry to the extreme.
Hazy orange with tiny head. Aroma is sour with citrus, abricot and woody notes. Very sour flavor with well hidden hints of abricot ;-) Lovely...

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 Thanx to Mgumby for sharing this.Pours a golden hay color with a white head.barnyard funk nose.Flavor is super sour fruit.This finished off with apples and sourness coming in on the backend.RERATE! HAd this on tap at RedLight on 01/17/09.I am not a sour head but man when they are fresh I enjoy them more and this was no exceptionThe sourness in the bottle was more tart fresh.The apricots came out more.Good stuff.

Huge thanks to mgumby for this one, thanks again Mike! My first one from these guys. Poured a cloudy golden color with a thin medium white head. The aroma was big of apricots, acidic sourness, and some funk. The aroma doesnt prepare you for the onsluaght of sourness to follow. The flavor was all of sour apricots and peaches with the acidity and sourness dominating the taste. There is a good amount of funk in there as well with all the sourness. It was enough to make you pucker up from all the sour taste. It was medium bodied with a sour dry finish with a nice long aftertaste. I really enjoyed this one, am digging the sour stuff.

Pours a cloudy gold color with a decent white head.  Smells of that classic Cantillon funk and acidity where you really dont get much else but that.  Its ok, Ive come to expect it from these guys.  The flavor is much the same.  I got just the slightest little apricot flavor because the funk and sourness is so overpowering, its toug to pull out other flavors.  Big cheek puckering acidity rules here, medium dry finish, with a lemony fruity aftertaste.  Another great showing.

Thanks Mgumby!  Huge apricot floral aroma, with some acidic sourness on the nose.  Pours Peachy yellow.  The flavor is awesome!  Sweet apricots, sour peaches, apple skins, great horseblanket feel, with sour dry finish.  The fruit flavor is so great.  Man this is a great lambic.  Theres almost a creamy mouthfeel in the aftertaste.

Bottle from BOE 07-10-07  Poured a wonderful murky orange colour and whilst quite fizzical there was no head. Aroma was tart but the apricots were definitely there. Tasted initially very acidic which took a while to wane but it did and then a strident fruitiness started to flood through with soft fleshy overripe apricots becoming more and more noticeable. This was a nice lambic but I felt that it needed time, initially I wasnt so fussed but owing to it being a rather large 750ml bottle I noticed that after 45-60 mins later it started tasting so much better. With time the vicious acid bite at the start seemed to mellow a touch obviously that was the case of ones palate getting used to it but also I like to think that maybe a bit of air and the slowing down of that carbonation might have helped.
From a bottle poured a slightly hazy golden color.  Nice tart flavor with all kinds of fruity flavoring.

This beer pours a cloudy golden color with nice laceing but a rather faded head. It has strong aroma of yeast and lamon citrus. As you drink it the flavor was very salty and it drys the sides of your mouth rather quickly. There was also some intence flavors of lemon and tons of citrus and hops.

I dont know what I expected, but I found complexity and some bright, fulsome fruit flavors that were awesome in this sour, dry acidic incarnation. Pours a translucent gold with a very active but disappearing white head. Incredible aroma of bright fruits, not just apricot but also nectarine, tangerine, orange, peach, with lighter notes of ginger and catty funk. Sour flavor, lemon with tart nectarine and apricot. Quite acidic, semi-dry, and only slightly musty in the back. Fun to drink. I should have expected it to be this good.

Corked 2006. Pours an opaque nectarine/creame colour filled with particulates and forms a swirl of white foam that clings to the rim of the glass. The aroma is certainly tart, with a funky bouquet of fruits, mostly apricot and barnyard. The nose is less abrasive than a gueuzes, but still pretty pungent. The flavour sour and salty, with vibrant overtones of strong acidic citrus, but not  so acidic that it resembles acetic acid. The apricots are very subtle. Musty yeast, acid and funk mask most of the apricot. The palate is tingly and soft with a drying finish.

&50ml bottle, says 2004 Vintage on the cork!Nose is funky with tartness and light apricots; lightly hazed and apricot colored with a small white head; flavor is sour, but not like a guezue, complemented by a very light taste of the apricots. Wish you could taste a little more apricots though!

750ml 2007 vintage. pours cloudy dull orange with small white head around the rim. nose is tart and semi-sour apricots with nice funk to it. flavor has nice tart and sour apricot fruit which is really refreshing. a nice balance here where the acidity is low. very well done.

Name: Fou Foune
Date: 02/21/2004
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, RateBeer SE Gathering, 2004

hazy light orange, light tart aroma, big tart flavor, just a hint of peach sweetness induced by reading the label

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.6/5.0Score: *4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Woosh! You wanna talk acidity, here it is. Funky aroma that is fruity, citrusy, with a touch of horseblanket. I cant tell that the fruitiness is apricot. Flavor is hard acidity, bordering on acetic, biting sourness, leading into a semi-dry finish. Fruitiness swirls in the background, again not obviously apricot. Some lemony citrus is present, possibly an illusion due to the acidity. Cloudy yellow color, fizzy, soft palate.
bottle, bottled in 2001. Cloudy orange colour, tiny head. Very sour indeed, which comes as now surprise however, flavours of apricot, slightly hoppy.
Purchased bottle from Obriens.  Your quinessential belgian Lambic thats perfect with the softest hints of apricot. What a nice refreshing beer this is.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2008 First tried at the Seattle International Beer Festival and then at the brewery in 2004. Hyper-tart apricot sour with considerable depth and complexity, good carbo level, and some pit bitters too. Beautiful beer.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2013 Re-rated in 2012. On tap @ Patricks. Hazy orange body with a small off-white head. Nice funky aroma with fruit and particular citric fruit. Flavor is sour acidic and somehow a bit sweet at the same time. Its not to funky but everything from a real lamic is present in a rather balanced way. Fine body and pleasant in aftertaste. A nice one for sure. 
   
750 ml bottle tasted in 2007. Pale, hazy orange body with a small white head. Aroma is really strange, sourness with a hint of mild vomit! Flavor is sour with sweet peaches. Not really balanced in my opinion. 2-3-4-3-6

Bottle @ Ølbaren.  [Huge thanks to Sk8viking for sharing this one]  Small fizzy head that was quickly goon. Clear flat body with a golden color. Aroma was the classic Cantillon famous aroma. Other notes of vinegar, dust, soap like, fresh apple, raw fruit like feel. Hint of raw rubber and light barnyard. Medium to full bodied with a soft carbonation and dry texture. Moderated sour flavor with light fruity sweet notes. Sour and lingering finish. Very nice.

Draft at Belmont Station: Pours golden with barely a head with white bubbles. Very sour  aroma. Flavor is slightly sweet and very very sour, i can just barely get some of the apricot in there but its so sour that takes over. Some musty yeastiness. Dry  finish. If you like sour you will love this. Not balanced at all.

On tap! at the Belmont Station Puckerfest 2007. Beautiful beer, sour and acidic as all cantillon beer, dry and earthy/dusty flavors with a lingering dry apricot finish. Pours cloudy orange with a soft white head that falls quickly. The apricot in this beer gave the impression of sweetness even though the beer is still very dry.

Bottle. Amber color with no head. You get more out of the apricots in the aroma than in the flavor, which was a small disappointment to me. But nevertheless its quite close to a gueuze with a hint of apricots. A bit special in the palate because of the very dry and at the same time sticky feeling you get in your mouth.

Tasted at the brewery - this was my favorite of the Cantillon lambics I had the chance to try.  Tart, sour, hints of apricots, and a dry finish... nevertheless, the style is so different to my palate that it would take more than a couple tastes to become accustomed to - but this pretty good.

Bottled - Swan & Rushes - Leicester.  A vibrant orange coloured beer, still as a snail.  The aroma is acidic with sweaty socks.  The taste is all you would expect.  Sournes, acidity, puckering.  Lovely to drink.  Only mildly fruity and not obviously brewed with apricots.  Again, lovely.

Cloudy peach/amber body. A small head forms and diminishes quickly, nearly fully. Aromas of light fruits that include apricots, peach, kiwi and unripe bananas are all notable but deeply buried under heavy funk. Notes of barnyard, sourness, leather, grain all combine to create a robust if not somewhat muddled, crazy nose. Light vinegar, even in fresh samples. Flavors of huge funk, dried fruits, sweet toasted malts and looming sourness. Medium acidity. Everything seems muddled together, but it really has a great overall taste. Its definitely a strange one. The finish is musty, fruity and very dry, huge funk and biting tartness lingering. The mouthfeel is lively even though carbonation isnt high, very tannic at times and sour throughout. Very good, very strange. I guess that means its right up my alley.

Bottle (Apteekki, Turku)
Very light cloudy orangy yellow. Aroma largely scrumpy (thats a big complement). Tastes very sharp and bit peachy, with only a later hint of apricot.

Forgot to rate this on the first go-round and its better (fresher) now.  Slightly cloudy gold, thin head.  Nose is a sizable apricot hit, then cantillon funk & wheat.  Flavor is probably the driest cantillion Ive ever had.  Super dry & acidic, lemon & apricot.  Some wheat but damn is this dry.  Fruit sweetness is semi-present in the finish.  Wonderful but a slow drinker to be sure.
Bottle sampled. Pours hazy copper/orange with no head at all. Aroma of fruit, funk, and acidic. the flavor is sweet apricots to start and finishes sour. I wasnt crazy about this one.

(Bottle, thanks rickgordon) Pours hazy, beautiful yellowish orange with green hints. Woody, Cantillon house acid like aroma with a nice fruitiness with apricots up front. Rather tart and dry in the nose. Full acid sour flavour with some wood and fruits, mostly citrus fruits like lemon, but also apricots. Tart and dry. Some unripe berries. Medium body. Very Cantillon-ish.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 Bottled. Thx rickgordon.
Hazy orange. Small white head.
Light fruitiness in the aroma from apricots. Very sour and dry with some fruity flavour.

Bottled. 
Cloudy pale yellow colour. Immensely sour aroma with gastric juice like citric acid. Low on the fruits as always with Cantillon with ripe citrus/grape peel. Very hardcore Lambic.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2014 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 6/10/20072005 bottle, thanks rickgordon!Shady golden color, white head. Sour apricot scent, marvelous. BillieMaria said "sweaty feet" where my reply was "if my shoes smelled like this Id sleep with them next to my pillow!". Huge dry sour taste that lingers forever, I love it! Very sour mouthfeel, no bitterness.9/4/9/4/18=4.4RerateBottle thanks to Nisse666! Sampled on September 1, 201275 cl, BB 12/2009, cork marked 2005Cloudy orange color, fizzy white head. Sour fruity scent. Very sour, mouth puckering, gut punching, apricots taste. Amazing! Puckering mouthfeel, no bitterness. Amongst the most sour beers Ive ever tasted.8/3/9/4/18=4.2Rerate75 cl bottle thanks to Nisse666! Sampled on December 21, 2013.Bottled 28 Aug 2012.Clear amber color, white head. Fruity, apricot, acidic scent. Acidic, sour, fruity taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, very low bitterness.8/4/9/3/18=4.2RerateBottle 75 cl on March 14, 2014, I got it a while back from Bierkompass. Bottled 28 Aug 2012.Clear golden color, fizzy white head. Apricot, fruity, acidic scent. Acidic, green, fruity, light bitter taste, some apricots. Fizzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.10/3/8/3/17=4.1RerateBottle 75 cl at Sweet & Sour, Sätila, 2014-08-30. Had this in my fridge a while, 2012 version.Hazy yellow color, white head. Apricot, sweet scent. Very acidic to sour taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, very low bitterness. Apricot aftertaste.9/4/9/3/19=4.4

Bottle.   A yellow hazed color with a white head.  Sour, barnyard, citrus and the expected gueuze aroma.  Sour yet smooth with a smoked fruit flavor and an apricot finish.  Thanks to the bachelor party crew for this one!

Wow!!  Very very sour, and this is from someone who loves Rodenbach Grand Cru.  Strong apricot...make that hugely strong apricot, slight vinegar and green apples.  Complex aroma, with hints of cheese.  A winner.

25.4 oz bottle.  Bottled in 2.004. Foggy gold with a touch of white froth.  Some sediment in the bottom.  Sour lemon and yeast with emergent apricot.  Unfolds just beautifully.  Taste is more sour than nose.  Initially tart lemon with hints of pineapple.  Apricot remains.  Fruitier as it warms.  Faint carb, medium light.  Finishes with a pleasant pucker and woody peach pits.
750 ml. thanks to padrefan,  Pours a cloudy orange with a white head.  Aroma of everything sour, lemons, apricots, and grapefruit.  Flavors of the same.  No really my style.
750 ml bottle shared with Padrefan.  Lots of sour apricot aromas.  More apricot in the flavor.  I usually dont think of apricot as a sour flavor, but it went nicely.  Very very good.
750 ml bottle from Obriens. Very nice mirky orangish golden color with a huge white frothy head. Very tart, sour, and very dry mouth feel. Very little sweetness. Very good lambic.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a weird cloudy straw/orange/gold with virtually no head.  Pungent sour aroma along with some yeast.  The flavor reminds me very much of biting into a lemon.  Totally sour which completely dominates the flavor of this beverage.  There were some grassy flavors in there as well.  If theres anything else going on with this beer, I cant detect it because it is being overrun by the sour flavor.  Thin, unappealing mouthfeel.

Got over a $10 discount because the guy at the register couldnt find this one in the system. Kick ass. Hazy orange with a small head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is dominated by tart lemons and has notes of barnyard action, lighter fruits, more acidity and a light malty sweetness. Medium to light body, enjoyable but not great... like most of the Cantillon beers for me.

Bottled in 2004.  Pours a cloudy pear into a tumbler.  Bright white head recedes to skim surface.  Pear, brett and apricot aromas. Sharp, sour aspirin and sulphur turning to ever so slight apricot.  Finish leaves me smacking my lips.

Aroma of aprikots (not too much) and citrus. Hazy, yellow-orange coloured with a thin, white, lasting head. Taste is quite sour/tart with citrus, aprikots, yeast and some oak. Quite a nice balance for a beer so sour. Refreshing palate. Well brewed.
750 ml bottle Light apricots smell, Orange body ,  sour (typical cantillon) too. apricot and oak in aroma  Another great beer from Cantillon.

Slightly clouded orange with a small white head. Not too much apricot in the aroma, surprisingly similar to the gueuze... perhaps a tiny bit of dried stonefruits. Nice tart fruity flavour, light dry apricot... perhaps some sweetness towards the finish, which combines well with the brilliant cantillon acidity. Could have been better if I drank it sooner, seemed the apricot was well on its way out (2005 bottle). Bloody good though.

Really attractive to look at; mid-sized head with decent coffee-like density.  Colour is a dullish glowing orange (does that make sense). Lovely nose; pongy and sour early, takes me straight back to Rue Gheude, good intensity. Opens and softens over 15 minutes to reveal much more obvious fruity apricot notes, almost to the extend youd be forgiven for thinking you were infact sniffing a botrytise semillon dessert wine, although theres no denying the sour lambic notes underpinning the impressove bouquet.  Palate destroys any notion this will be a friendly fruity beer - sour, tangy, almost salty, pongy sulphuric notes. Truck loads of lemon and citrus with a touch of acid burn. Surprisingly all this flavour doesnt translate into a long or memorable finish. My bottle was very low fizz, and me thinks a few more bubbles may have carried the sour and citrus flavours better as the beer finished up feeling a touch flabby, as strange as it may seem.

(2006 bottling purchased at the brewery in October 2006)
Peach, grape aroma. Apricot and yeast taste. Nice colour, lemon with a small white head.
Bottle.  Bright golden beer with a light head.  The aroma is fruity and slightly strawberry and the flavour is sour and dry.  Overall an alright sour beer.

Pretty tasty brew, On tap at stuffed sandwich, no real aroma of Apricot, but nice Apricot aftertaste, not dominating, just there enough, plenty of great sourness, dust, Tartness, a very drinkable brew

On tap at Stuffed Sandwich, 2005 Vintage.  Pours the color of golden peach flesh with a thin layer of bubbly white head.  The aroma is a sour bouquet of apricots and spicy lemon notes, dusted with white pepper and accompanied by a young alder woodiness.  Light bodied, tingling carbonation with a hefty puncy of sourness.  Quite sour and not very funky, but pleasantly clean tasting.  The apricots are definitely there, but so are some white grape, granny smith apple skins, and a bite of raw melon rind.  Bone dry.  The sourness hits the tongue hard, assaulting it with a balanced barrage of apricot and woody white vinous notes which linger on the palate through a long finish, finally dissipating to leave a natural unsweetend apricot smack on the tongue.  Very satisfying, and one I wish I could afford to use as an everyday drinker.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2011 re-rate. First time i had this was over 4 years ago, and it was not a fresh bottle. this on was bottled agust 25th 2011. Boy oh boy, this is pretty close to perfect. 
the light subtle peachy apricot aroma is just intoxicating. There are some great funk barnyard aromas, some great sourness. some wet hay, and quite a bit of acidity. the fruit seems to tame the tartness though. The acidity, and apricot just blend together as one, and are just unbelievable. I cant get my nose out of the glass! the finish is light, bright, refreshing. medium sour, bright tropical fruit. lingering sourness. good god, this is amazing stuff!

On tap at Stuffed Sandwich, vintage unknown. Not cheap, but one of the best lambics Ive had on tap. Pours a cloudy tangerine color with very little head. Aroma is of tart apricot. Taste is much more tart and quite sour as well, but is very nice and not overwhelming. The apricot is present, but doesnt stand up to the strong sour characterstics. I really enjoyed the brew, and thought it was a bit more drinkable than the Lou Pepe Pure Kriek.

750ml bottle. The cork says it was bottled in 2006.  Purchased at the Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA. Pricey bottle, but I love Cantillon and never had this so I thought what the hell.  Drank in my new Lindemans flute.  Its kind of like drinking Alesmith in a Hieneken glass but not exactly.  The color is a slightly cloudy clear yellow.  The head poured whie and quite large and dissapated to a fingers worth and bright white.  The nose is full of apricot, and sour winey gueze like vibes.  It has been a long time since I have eaten an apricot but I can certainly taste it in the bottle.  The taste is tart and sour and light and tasty.  It is certainly more sour than a real apricot but it has an essence of the taste.  Its quite good, not very sweet at all.  I like it, dont know if Ill have it again soon, but it is great.

Thanks to Degarth for this bottle.  The pour is a hazy dark orange with a thin white head.  The aroma is vinuous with light fruit hints and definite sour scents.  The palate is full, and more sticky than most lambics--with great carbonation.  The taste is a ton of sour that socks you in the face--this coming from a guy who considers this his favorite style--so it is definitely sour.  Lots of wood flavors and maybe a hint of apricot--but not much at all.  The sour is a little too much throughout, and the other flavors dont present themselves strongly enough to make this as enjoyable as most Cantillon products.
Get a very sour aroma with some slight apricot.Pours a hazy orange with very little head.Very sour with some light fruit in the flavors.Medium mouthfeel with a bitter sour finish.

Many thanks to eaglefan538 for sharing this fairly expensive bottle with me, thanks Brian! Poured a small white head, fair retention with spotty lace. Seriously hazy, gold, glowiing yellow colored brew. Nose is large, leathery, bretty,fruity with peaches, green apples apricot? and citrusy notes hiding in there also. Body is light, tart, sour puckering mouthfeel. Lots of funkiness here, wet leather, some oxydation and peachy flavors climbing out from underneath it all. Dry, tart, fruity and over the top! Sour, tart, WOW !! Cantillon, Whao....

Bottle. 2006 Vintage. Hazy straw-amber beer with no head. Slight tart aroma with some indistinct fruitiness. Nice refreshing tart flavor with funk, dust, apples, citrus and ending in apricots. Tart/sour lingers with a bit of that apricot fruitiness. Medium bodied. Great flavor in great balance. Not as dry as other Cantillons Ive had and theres a bit of sweetness.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2011 Bottle. Hazy yellowish with a minimum of white head. Citrus and sour in aroma with apples, cellar and chewing gum. Flavour is sour and fresh with citrus and cellar aslo present. Re-rate on Draught @Ølbutikken. Original rating 8-3-5-3-13-3.2.

Cloudy orange with zero head.  Sour slightly floral aroma.  At first there is a slight hint of apricot in the nose and the taste but it is not something that overwhelms you.  Sour and bitter taste dominates as a lambic should.

(Bottle 75 cl) Pours a hazy, pale amber with an almost completely absent head. Sourish, fruity nose. Medium body with a marked, vinegary sourness. Not too sure I can pick up the apricots though. Sour all the way through. 291006

Bottled at Cantillon on public brew day. At first I feared this would be not good. I soon changed my mind.. Still cant believe how this can actually be more sour than their other stuff.. Its like theyve taken their Cantillon sour-amp and turned all the way up to... eleven
Bottle at Horsens beerfestival. Golden/orange colour with a white head. Aroma is sour, fruit, yeast. Flavour is fruit, orange, citrus, yeast.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2010 Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Unclear, yellow-orange with a small, white head. Barnyard, yeast  and citrus, mostly lime, in the aroma. The flavor is lemony and sour with yeast. Thin, very astringent beer with a dry, dusty feeling. Its nice, but maybe too thin and sour. Rating: 8-4-8-4-16-4. 061028Bottle, 75cl, at Esbjerg Beerfestival. Its a hazy, orange beer with a minimal off-white head. Barnyard, lemon and other funky niceness in the aroma. Slighlty rubbery flavor, with barnyard, horseblanket and lots of lemon. Bonedry, astringent and sour mouthfeel. Lemony finish. Almost lip-burning dry, maybe a bit one-dimensional lemony, but sure lovely. 091023

Bottled in 2004, poured a golden color with a flat head, no lacing (probably left the glassware squeeky clean, these cantillon guys). The aroma was funk, leather, peaches, and apricots. The flavor followed the aroma, strong initial tartness, peaches, citrus notes, funky horseblankets / brett, and traces of wheat under it all. The mouthfeel was strongly acidic (surprise), leaves the mouth squeeky clean. One of the stronger fruit presences in a Cantillon, yet still darned Cantillon-like in tartness. Rather refreshing.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 One of the easyiest to drink cantillons there must be. Aroma is cantillon trough and through yeasty sour hen shed lemon goodness. Taste is similar with somehting holding back the complete blow your mind typical sourness which i assume is the peach but i cant actually tell its peach unless i look at the bottle, making is closer to balanced than most cantillons though with more hops also. A very intresting and lovely lovely beer. RERATE: UP TO 4.7 FROM 4. Alround such an excellent beer, sort palat clensing yet sessionable, the fruit is subtle and sweetens it slightly but, my god its amazing.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 Bottle 750ml.Clear dark golden / yellow with a white head. Aroma is sour, fruity, somewhat funky. Taste is apricot, tart sourness, and some brett.  8-3-7-3-16 
Bottle 750ml. [ Vintage 2011 ]. Clear medium orange colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy, apricot, light barnyard. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light acidic with a average to long duration, fruity - apricot fresh. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20120127]  8-2-8-4-16 
Bottle 750ml. [ Vintage 2005 ]. Clear medium orange colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate leather, barnyard notes, light apricot, fruit. Flavour is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy acidic with a long duration, dry, barnyard, apricot, tart. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat [20120127]  8-2-9-4-18

Bottle.  The inside of the cap is covered with a grey mold on this bottle and the cork is leaking.  But, since the underside of the cork looks good, Im gonna drink it anyway; if I havent logged on in few days send someone for my body.

Pours a yellow color with a slight haze.  Quickly dissipating white head and only a slight carbonation that may a result of the leaking cork.  Fruity aroma with some fresh straw and some light barnyard notes.  Tart and acidic with a strong apricot fruitiness.  The fruit flavor is very sweet while the lambic sourness tends to conflict it.  This beer really has two separate personalities.  The typical Cantillon Funk saves the taste for me.  Without it, it trends towards some of the sweet alco-pops some of the other Lambic Brewers are sending to the states.   Slightly sweet/ sour finish as well.
intresting fruity nose, sour acidic fruity taste champagne like nice amount of head very dry finish.
on tap at the belgian room, Hop Devil Grill.  Light orange with a large off white head.  Aroma is pretty funky with fruit also.  Taste is funky, fruity, and very sour.
Absolutely gorgeous liguid sunshine. PEachs and apricots with lemon zest and blood orange with a grapefruit finis. Extremely wel melded lambic that makes me want to lick it off of Tyra Banks.
I like the cap/cork combo. This (special vintage?) lambic requires an open mind to appreciate. The first taste is an explosion of Sweet-Tarts on acid. Subsequent tastes are pretty similar.

2002 vintage 750 ml bottle into a Flute.  Pours a beautiful lightly hazed peach golden color with a fizzy head at first that dies quickly.  The aroma comes off with a tart peach and apricot astringent nose with daisy flowers tossed in the bunch.  The flavor first hits a sweet apricot note which quickly moves into a very sharp and tart grassy gueze note that fizzes into a very dry spiced and sour finish which coats the teeth in a very interesting way.  Quite the brew.  Was a bit expensive, but its also a 2002 vintage.  Definitely worth at least $20 if you can find a 2006 vintage.
Bottled. Pours a clear dark golden, with a white head. Aroma is sour, fruity, somewhat funky. Taste is apricot, tart sourness, and some brett.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 I had this a long time ago. A re-rate must take place some time in the future. My taste has developed a great deal since.

Bottle from Super Saver.  Turbid gold orangy pour with 1-finger off-white head.  Aroma of heavy tart fruit, a lot of peachy and apricotty hints, with some earthy citrus.  The flavor is very tart and citric, with peach and apricot notes, and some arthy peaty malty notes.  As with all Cantillons, this one has no sweetness whatsoever, and gets like a pulpy unsweetened grapefruit juice as it warms.  This is the last of the Cantillons that I pay 20 bucks for.  Im officially writing off beers that make my lips pucker worse than squeezing a lemon directly into my mouth.  Even gueuzes have more non fermented sugars that this!

Bottle, Københavnske Øldage 2006. Slightly golden orange and a little hazy. Distinct barn-yardy nose with a distinct apricoty aroma. Sour apricot flavours. Too bad I had this one at the end of the flight. Will try it again at some other time.
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow colour with a small white head. Sour barnyard aroma with some fruity hints. Sour tart fruity flavor with some hints of apricot. Has anice tart fruity finish.
Bottle at Ølbaren, shared with Mette, recommended by Sahlholdt. Orange, small white head. Sour acid, fruit (peach), citrus, some wood. A little like biting a peach, the sour/sweet skin.
Dark, hazy yellow color. Small head.  Citric aroma with a hint of apricot. Very sour sucking-on-a-lemon flavour. Some apricot flavour lurks in the background.
Bottle. Milky, cheesy, sour/citric aroma. Very cloudy yellow colour. Nice head. The flavour is very citric with some danablue. Nice acidity, burning at the back of my throat.

On tap at the Maproom!!!  Poured a lightly hazy orangey-apricot with a half inch of white headage.  Loved the funky/sweet/sour/tart nose... old moldy, cobwebby stable,  bread, and mild spices accented with a lighter-than-expected apricot presence.  Flavor was even better... lip puckering, stomach-eroding vinegar and lemon, funky yeast, ripe cheese, and overtones of apricot.  Powerful in every sense of the word, yet intricately crafted, engaging, and truly refreshing.  Rather dry.  This was a most excellent brew!
Cloudy orange colour with a very small white head. Fruity and lactic sour aroma. Tart fruity flavor with notes of yeast and wood.

on tap at map room...I thought this was pretty delicious.  Poured a flat rosey color.  Aroma was intense tarty sweet fruit and sour champaign.  Flavor was similar...very much like white wine with some great light fruitiness and barn funk.  Mouthfeel was light and refreshing.
Lightly sour with hints of apricot tartness.  Yeasty fruit notes with a complicated interplay of wood barrel, barnyard,  and mustiness.  Typically high quality lambic from this brewer.

Tap at Spuyten Duyvils yeast feast - probably one of the least sour of Cantillons lambics, but, as anyone experienced with them knows, that doesnt mean it isnt still mouth-puckering - cloudy burnt gold/orange - lovely wild yeast and white wine aroma, with just a small undercurrent of tart apricot - the sourness seems less like a wild yeast sourness, and more like they used under-ripe fruit to lend a different kind of tartness to this particular beer - woody, barnyard, characteristically Cantillon flavor abounds underneath - and under THAT, an almost alcoholic, tannic, wine-like flavor - very complex stuff, but even with the lower sourness, its still hard to drink more than a few ounces in a sitting.

Bottled 2005. Well it certainly looks like an apricot beer (not that I can think of any other apricot beers Ive had) - hazy orange with a sparse head. The first thing I noticed about this one was that the aroma didnt make my mouth pucker up before even tasting it like most Cantillons do, which as it turned out was a harbinger of things to come. This was quite unlike most other Cantillons Ive had. Distinct peppery lichen aroma with not much apricot character, though perhaps theres some of the skins and an earthy stem character. The house lambic character does eventually come through, but remains restrained at all times with bits of wood, cobwebs, stale hops and aged cheddar peeking through. Whereas the aroma had only a subtle hint of apricot, the flavour is simply bursting with apricot character in the most delicious way. It tastes like tart, dry, apricot nectar with the acidity of dried apricots. The initial sensation is slightly milky, and perhaps even a touch alkaline, and the finish is very clean with a touch of pungent hop. Lambic character is minimal. It gives the impression that most of the acidity is generated by the fruit, not the lambic, and I like it. A lot. Delicious stuff, the best Cantillon Ive had in quite a while. It really goes to show the benefit of getting into them quickly before all the fruit character disappears.

Hazy peach juice color with suspended particles and pulpy bits floating around underneath a small white head. Moderate/high carbonation. Aroma is acidic,funky,musty,fruit,citrus. Flavor is citrus,acidic,tart,astringent with mild peaches. Fuller body than any lambic I had recently.

Draught snifter at RedBones. Pours a flat hazy light orange color.  Nose is light citrus fruits, apricots are noticed. Has a light bit of sourness in the nose. Flavor is sour as hell. One of the more sour cantillons I have experienced. Some great flavorful citrus surrounds the flavor and leaves the palate hurting and swollen. It is a wild roller coaster ride for your palate. Finish is crisp and refreshing, very nicely done.
bottle. murky orange color. grape and apricot scent. very dry. roastet pallet.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2016 750cl. Hazy orange with little white head. Smells, looks and feels like a cantillon product. Very sour, but this has a little bit of sweet in the end from the abracot feel! Great! Bottle @ Too many geuzes only one toilet, Ulfborg 2012. Wauw. Tasted 2005 and 2011. 2001: Fresh fruit - really fresh apricot. Young vaguely tart 4.. 2005: Horse manuer, barnyard, light fruit and pungeantly tart! 4,3. Re-rate 2016. Fresh.. Apricot, funk and barn. Complexity! Top 10 sipper for me.

Aroma:sour and cheese..
Appearance:hazy yellow,light head...
Flavor:very good citrus sour flavor...

This bottled brew was sampled at the RateBeer gathering at Dicks Bodacious Bar-B-Que.  It poured a fully diminished non-existent head and a body of light orange brown color.  The aroma was tingly hoppy and oh so lambic like.  The mouth feel tingly and sour from start to finish.  The flavor contained sour malty farmhouse notes.

Not the usual, funky, barnyard Cantillon drink.  Pours a very hazy, pale orange color with a creamy white head.  The nose is very acidic, a sour fruit aroma, apricot with tart oranges and lemons. Light bodied with a tongue cleansing astringency.  The apricot recedes in the flavor, returning in the finish, but shadowed by the sour lemon and zest of lemon, tart oranges, and a touch of straw.  Nice dry finish.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Chicago (Downtown), IL<font size=-1>

750ml bottle poured a cloudy yellow orange with a small lingering white head. Aromas of citrus, muskiness, spice and light apricot. Palate was light bodied and tart. Flavors of lemon, some muskiness and hints of apricot with the glorious tart lingering Cantillon finish!
Bottle. Cloudy with no head. Semi dry - slightly "dusty" in flavour. Also flavour of dried abricots. Very good.

Tasted at the 2006 Pizza Port Belgian Fest. This fruit lambic pours a light yellow very hazy gold color from a 750ml bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity, tart, sour and dry. Touch of apricots. A medium bodied lambic. Malts are fruity, with a prevalent apricot flavor.  Intensly dry with a nearly mouth puckering tartness. Very dry, nearly Berliner Weiss in tartness. Still there is a strong malt and fruity backbone under all that tartness. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean, crisp and dry. Aftertaste is tart.
Very sour in aroma, very cloudy with no head.  This is a bitter beer that makes you pucker up but crave it more and more with each sip!

Sample at Indy tasting Dicks BBQ 3/31/06 - Aroma has a sour soapy nose with lemon, apricot, and yeast.  Pours cloudy muddy yellow with no head or lacing.  WOW!  Pucker up, this baby is sour.  Lots of citrus, apricot, and yeast.  Palate is very tart.  Interesting and tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2006 Bottle at Cantillon. Light yellow orange in color. Apricot and grapefruity tart aroma. Citrusy notes. Sour and citrusy flavor. Very dry finish. Nicely carbonated. Medium bodied. Well balanced. Finish is apricot. Very nice.  Very enjoyable.
Sweet apricot with tart notes. Cloudy and nectar-like. This reminded me of a bellini. Light straw color. Very tart and grapefruity.

(75cl Bottle.  03/2006)  Delicious.  Initial aromas are all funk just as youd expect from a Cantillon -- all the distinctive Cantillon aromas are there.  Hazy straw/orange.  Expected barnyard flavors.  Wonderful palate -- perfectly medium-full with lively carbonation and a long finish.  Then I let this breathe ... about half an hour into it (I had left some in a glass) it was like smelling and eating an apricot ... amazing.  This is a great beer.

2004. Hazy gold. Fizzy, white head settles quickly. Nose- musty, sour, spicy yeast and pungent, past ripe apricot. Same flavor. Very sour and a bone dry finish. Apricot is a perfcet choice for a lambic. Medium, balanced body. The best fruit lambic Ive had.

[ Bottled ; chilled ; 2004 vintage ]

A fully diminushing small fizzy white head that tops up a hazy medium orange body. No lacing. No particules. No bubbles. Aroma of apricot, orange juice with a sharp tarness/sourness. Hay/leather/horseblanket/barnyard/dust... well, a Cantillon/brett. To the mouth, apricot for a fraction of a second, then tartness hits and holds for a while. acidic of course, but well rounded. Dry but sugary. Another wonderful Cantillon.

750 ml bottle. Pours orange with a - for a lambic -quite fine head that lasts a while. The aromas are classic Cantillon; limey, sweaty and moldy. A hint of tobacco there also. And then there is the apricot aroma, which enhances the citric component even more. On the palate it is absurdly acidic, but still fruity. Complex, with a mouthfeel like a mixture between freshly squeezed lemon, grape fruit and orange juice. Not my favourite Cantillon, but still a super beer!

Bottled in 2004, hazy yellow hue, with almost no head, only a shy white ring of foam, the nose is offring the characteristic personality of cantillon, with his tartness, vinous and sournesss aspects, the apricot fruitiness seems to be hidden in the oakiness, but we can perceive the sweetness of the fruit in the traditional lambic aroma. Follows through an energetic yeastiness from the brettanomyces, unfolding some percing tartness and sourness flavors, to allow the shyness of the apricot to emerges in the acidic immensity of the lambic, leading towards a long intense winey and dry finish.

2004 bottle. pours a hazy yellowish orange. huge  cantillon funk dominates the nose with mild apricots and lemon. mouth puckering tartiness, more funk and vinegar take over the palate. yummy. goes very nice with Hopistotle420s birthday carrot cake. Happy birthday benny boy!

2004 bottle, sampled with the Montreal crew at the "lets make Clark jealous" tasting.

Sunny and peachy orange like a tropical sunset or a really bad 80s T-shirt, it sported a thin white lacing.

One whiff and Kapow!  The usual Cantillon rainbow of aromas that youre not supposed to like but still do, the hay, the pig pen, old baseball mit and grandmas old photo album are there, but the fruit seems much more present, as if it were served with a twist of orange.
If it were any more acidic than this, it would puncture your stomach.  But the fruit shines beautifully once again, showing oranges, tangerines, peaches and a little passion fruit.  Finish is sharp and dry, but with a very long tongue flipping aftermath.  The drinkability of this elixir was strongly debated amongst the crew, and as usual concensus was not achieved.  I was on the "yes" side, because I already dusted off a 750 by myself in Brussels, however I didnt enjoy the bottle I had at Delirium Café as much as this one.  But I agree with the fact that this isnt for everyone.  Im not saying this to pass off as a snob, Im just saying that there isnt enough Pepsid AC, Rolaids or Tums on earth to cure what this Beer would do to anyone with ulsers or acid reflux.
We had this first, figuring that Rastacouere, who was late, wouldnt mind missing this, it turned out to be one of the surprise winners of the show!  Just goes to show that Cantillons can still surprise you, and that bottle-to-bottle variability can lead to startling results.
Pours a milky yellow, almost a mustard aroma to it.  Definatel lambic pucker to it.  Half way through theres a punch of breadyness that vanishes quickly leaving the pungent behind.

"Poured a yellow color with a small head with very little lacing. Aroma was lemony and of some other fruit. Taste was so like sucking on a tart lemon, there was another fruit flavor that i couldnt figure out. Very sour. Still not liking lambics."

A Mes rate:
75cl bottle from Battersea Beer Festival! Quite impressed they had this to be honest. Typical lambic nose but with a little more funk than you would usually expect from Cantillon. I mean seriously funky. Its almost James Brown. Wonderful hazy golden appearance. Taste is just what you would expect from Cantillon but where is the apricot? Ah there it is. Not even a hint of it until the finish then it hits you just hard enough to leave a glorious creamy and tropical aftertaste. A most unusual experience for a lambic. Yes all the characteristics you would expect are there but cream? And obvious sweetness? Very very heavy sediment for my final pour. Sim wouldnt drink it. I gave it a good home. Great stuff and a little deviation from the norm.

Hazy golden lambic with a thin white head. Pleasant apricot aroma with horseblanket and cheesey notes. Good fresh apricot pulp in mouth, with some sour cherry notes, and lactic points. Excellent ! Sampled at Quintessence Cantillon 2005.

Sampled at Oakes 05 Xmas PartyCloudy banana color with puffy cloudy head. Nose is moist, yeasty, soiled hay, a bit tart and vinous. The flavor is tart, as expected, but a bit too much; too vinous. I like a good balance of sour vinegar taste and funk in a Lambic and it isnt here. Still an awesome quaffing beer but I start to sweat after drinking too much of this. And trying to down a whole swallow is going to need a moment to recoup.

Golden, almost yellow, with the characteristic fine white small-bubbles foam. It reduced to a film, though. Apricot aromas lening in with refreshing lemon. Initially very acidic, lots of lemon, mellowing towards the finish with the apricots taking more centre-stage together with hints of almond.  Medium-bodied, medium carbonation, dry finish. An amazingly complex beer.

750ml. bottle, enjoyed at the Spuyten Duyvil. Hazy yellow/orange color with a small white head. Funky, musty aroma of  tart apricots and hints of bleu cheese. Huge citric acid sourness to this beer. I love tart and this is one of the most tart beers Ive ever tried. The apricot flavor was much more subdued than the aroma, just a hint of the fruit. Excellent, as always from Cantillon.

75cl bottle at GBBF, August 2005.  I could have sworn Id rated this before, so didnt make very extensive notes. Seems I hadnt rated it. Fruity, but Im not sure I would have spotted it as apricot had I not known, Typical Cantillon stuff. Funky aroma, very sour and tart, but clean and refreshing. Very gueuze like for a fruit lambic. Nice.

0.75 L bottle, bbe Dec 09. Shiny, fluorescent, light honey colour, very turbid, minimal head with some lace sticking to the edge of the glass. Rotten, eggish, sour aroma with good floral notes but also some rubber. Sour and dry taste with clearly and wonderfully present apricot. A bit more fruit than lambic in a good combination of the two. Solid body, light carbonation, very dry mouthfeel.

Apricot colored liquid below a small, slowing forming head.  Initially bright and vibrant fruit aroma of apricot and peach, which becomes less apparent as the bottle nears final consumption.  Other aromatic Cantillon lambic qualities are also present, but in a subtle way.  Unbelievably harsh citric acid flavor, with very little character besides an extreme amount of sourness.  This is an unbelievably intense lambic, probably the most sour lambic ever.  Its so strange, because I adore the three year old Grand Cru, but that beer has so much more depth and character, besides the sourness.  This is just cutting, with very little fruit character.

Bottled 75cl, vintage 2003
Pale yellow-orange, no head. Sour nose, fruits and horse blanket in it. Bone dry (it cant get much drier), same  time deliciously fruity. For sure, the best apricot lambic you can get.

Bottle @ Den Tatoverede Enke, Cph. The aroma is quite sweet yet very tart, notes of peaches, really dry. Hazy yellow body, with a small white head. Extreme sourness, followed by notes of grape fruit. Bone dry. Thanks to tbone_ for sharing this magnificent beer.
This one is quite sour. I like the combination of the exotic fruit at the sourness. Not artificial, as if Cantillon would ever be. The only good apricot beer Ive tried.

Initially pours pretty clear out of the bottle but immediately turns very hazy and opaque straw yellow/light gold.  Very minimal head and no lace.  Aroma is very complex, yet it isnt all that inviting.  Initially some fruit is noticed as you pop the cork, along with some woody notes, but when it is cool you can notice a lot of sour notes, mixing heavily with a lot of musty aromas as well as lots and lots of sulfur compounds.  Some sulfur dioxide, and a bunch of different thiols I cant pinpoint.  Some of the aromas are very similar to those found in a fermenting lager, or those that come from weihenstephan yeast with respect to the sulfur.  As it warms more and more sour and musty barnyard smells come up along with a hint of fruit- apricot-peach like.  Dear lord this is some sour stuff.  First sip is like tasting a sour warhead- maybe even more sour.  This is really mouthpuckering yet I cant seem to stop tasting it.  Lots of sour notes up front with lactobacillus, then a bit of the fruit in the end.  I expected a lot more fruit in this lambic- but only got a minimal amount.  Obviously this is very dry due to its acidity.  Not sure If I will be able to drink this whole bottle by myself, but it is so unique that Ill give it a try.  I got really lucky with this bottle being that it only cost me $11 in brooklyn (obviously a mismarked bottle) instead of the usual $20-25 per bottle.  Very good overall, but Ill take any of the Lou pepes anyday over this.
[PIBF 04] Bottle. Cloudy pinkish in color. Very sour barn nose. Very sour apricot like flavor. (I know it is apricot but it is hard to find under all the horse blanket flavors).

Wow, Sourest lambic Ive come across so far. Incredibly dry, acidic, lighter apricot. Very refreshing. Awesome stuff but this isnt for newbies. The sourness will suck your lips down your throat if youre not too careful.

Pours hazy golden color with no head. Aroma has a very strange sourness to it. Wohlfs brought up "perm solution" which I will have to agree with. Flavor is a very nice sour/tart balance with only a hint of apricot. Very nice brew if you can get past the aroma.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2006 Pours a hazy blonde color with a ring of white lace. Acid, tart aroma of apricot, typical Cantillon wildness. Acid, tart and mouthpuckering flavor of apricot, again this reeks of Cantillon a lot, their wild yeast signature is there, theres a good dose of funk and its also citric. The mouthfeel is dusty and dry. Great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2006 Couleur jaune paille allant vers le doré, pratiquement aucune mousse, faible et nonchalant dégagement gazeux laissant initialement de grosses bulle sur le rebord du verre.  Arômes semblant très acide, vieux barils de bois humide, quelque peu herbal sous de faible parfum dabricots dominé par les citrons.  Plein de caractère sauvage, typique brettanomyces.  Les caractéristiques du fruit sont abstraites au début et prennent de lampleur au fur et à mesure que le liquide se réchauffe, devenant ainsi bien reconnaissables et plaisantes.  Très tartrique et acide en bouche, semblant pleinement atténuée, présence du blé devenant plus marquée vers la fin.  Très appréciable et typique de Cantillon.  Bouteille achetée à la brasserie, Avril 2005.

Sample shamelessly mooched from Stephen Beaumonts bottle. Cloudy, milky orange body. Aroma reminds me of French Chardonnay, sour grapefruit, and stonefruit. Funk and yeast are prominent, then again my sample wasnt the cleanest. Ultra sour flavor, seemingly beyond maximum threshold. Intense horse blanket and ripe stone fruit complexity. Great beer. Will definitely re-visit.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2005 Bottle:  Courtesy of Styles.  Very sour and tart aroma with a light mustiness.  Pours a very cloudy dull yellow with a small white ring for a head.  Very sour and tart from start to finish with a light acidity in the finish.  So sour and tart that apricot, or any other flavor for that matter, is completely dominated and covered up.

Bottle from Styles.  Opaque yellow-orange colored with a slight white head.  Aroma is very sulfury, reminding me of what a hair shop on permanent day smells like. Light to medium bodied.  Well carbonated.  A bit sulfury in flavor but not enough to detract from the sour barny flavors.  A touch of apricot shows through.  Tart.  Nice beer but the sulfur smell really detracts for me.

Bottle #34 of 180, bottled in 2000 and consumed at Toronado, San Francisco. This bright orange lambic poured with a thin white head, eliciting a sharp citrus-like aroma. There is a delicate apricot flavor, with a very dry palate and a tart lemon finish.  I have enjoyed many of the Cantillon brews, and this was my favorite.
Light orange in colour. Apricot?! More like a big dry gueuze. Intensely dry, big sour mouthfeel. Mild fruity aroma. Very refreshing and morish, but hard to find the apricots there! Still tasty.
(on bottle) A vague sent here. The taste is also just sour, then, out of nowhere, the abricots sets in. Long finish of the same, the abricots makes this a very mild lambic.

Bottled @ KØ 2005: Light golden coloured. Unclear. Medium sized white head. Abricot, light sweet sourness in the aroma. Has the typical earthy notes. Flavour as well is sour brilliantly held up by the sweetness. Some hay, tart and fruit notes. Ends on a fruity sourness and is refreshing and cleansing. Used this a twice as palatecleanser during the festival.

A typical Cantillon.  Poured a lovely shimmering orange, smelled of lemons, acid and apricots, and went down like a shot of Drano, causing rumblies in my tummy.  But while in my mouth, it was a nice mix of citrus, apricot, and lots of sourness.  Could have used a bit more apricot to balance it out, but good nonetheless.
Cloudy light orange with a somewhat lasting white head. Aroma is light barnyard. Taste is tart as hell. Some apricot, brett and leather. As tart of a Cantillon that Ive had.

Orange-yellow colour without lasting head. Taste is of course sour, but with some mildly sweet apricot taste to balance things out...still new to this style and find it quite challienging,  but I think this is the best one so far.
Hazy orange yellow with fast disapearing white head. sour and sweet aroma with notes of citrus. Taste is sour  with note of apricot.

Hazy orange-yellow colour, low dissapearing head. Acidic aroma of lemon peels, leather and barnyard. tart and very sour flavour of orange skins, hay and lemon. Wheres the apricot? Tart and sour aftertaste of lemon-peels and hay. Good but not the best Cantillon.

Cloudy orange colour with a small head.
Aroma of sour milk, abricots and unriped fruit.
Sour flavour dominated by unriped fruit  with notes of abricots. Slightly bitter finish.
One of the first lambics Ive had, and Im not used to the sour flavour yet.
Interesting.

Cloudy orange with a small head.  Aromas are sour, musty and cheesy.  I can smell the apricot behind the farmyard aromas.  Flavours are very sour, perhaps the most sour Cantillon I have had.  Musty as expected.  Has lots of lemon juice notes towards the finish.  Dry and sour on the palate.  Another excellent Cantillon brew.

Hazy orange colour with a tiny wisp of a head. Aroma is funky, cheesy & sour. Very complex flavour, similar to the regular gueuze but with more sour fruit notes. Very tart and dusty tasting, with nice apricot notes in the middle. The flavour changed as the beer warmed - I can only describe it by saying that the warmer it got, the "older" it tasted. I havent had enough real gueuzes and lambics to completely get my head around them, but I know what I like, and I liked this a lot.
Brewtopia 05. Yellow body with little head.  Sour aroma, apricot nose.no apricot taste how ever, but not bad eitherway.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2008 Bottle... Spring Brewtopia 2005... This beer rocks!... This is just a touch darker than freshly squeezed lemon juice and just about as sour. Dont really pick up any of the apricot. Tastes and smells like lemon juice aged in oak. Lively carbonation. This is the most sour beer I have ever had. Kicks La Folies ass on the sourness scale... sorry New Belgium. Cabbage Patch Kids are honey-sweet compared to this. My nose and ball hair tingle each time I take a sip. I love spontanious fermentation. Liquid fun!

04.16.05  Brewtopia 05, 750ml bottle.  Yellow white and completely muddy.  Ring of white head.  Huge cheese, foot, funk, sock aromas.  Lots of apricot on nose (I had no idea this was supposed to be an apricot beer until I asked some people).  Only hints of fruity skin in flavor while its dominated by a glorious and harshly acidic tartness.  Great aromas, fabulous palate, but the flavor is not too unique.

Sampled at Brewtopia 2005.  Poured golden and hazy, effervescent with a white head.  Strong aroma of tart apricots.  Taste is... wow... tart, tart, tart apricots.  Like sucking on an apricot sour candy.  Dry finish.  This could be repugnant to some, but I like sour, so this is right up my alley.

bottle at smokeless joes. hazy golden yellow colour. no head. wow! funky sour tart fruitiness in the aroma. you could smell it from quite a distance. I could only detect very faint notes of apricot. oh my... this is quite tart, mouth-puckeringly tart. bone dry with a ridiculously long sour finish. awesome!

UPDATED: APR 17, 2005 75cl bottle, corked says bottled in 2000, hand numbered "#22 of 180"  So can you smell acid?  Cuz this smelled like acid! & not the trippy kind...I think that all the apricot character has vanished from this...maybe a bit remains in the layers of the aroma and the twanging finish...this has barnyard horse blanket sweat hay all over it, with a lingering tartness that goes on...and on...Laura tasted it and said "Ive had bile that tasted better than that!"  Not for everybody...but once youve acquired the taste for all things sour, it doesnt dissapoint...and the bottle grows on me more and more as I go thorugh it!  It does seem to be a bit heavier than a gueuze and it is certainly an apricot color. whoa This thing is so acidic...the Cantillon funk is massive here, and maybe heightened by the apricots?

Pours a yellow-golden beer with a thin snow white head. The aroma is extremely fresh with a slightly acidid apricot note and hints of grapefruit - very summer! The flavor doesnt show as much apricot, but is tart and biding with a dry grapefruit and lemon note. Maybe not as interesting as some of the top notch Cantillon but still extremely fresh and very well balanced. Definately one of the best summer drinks I can think of.

RATING #1700.Acidic apricot aroma.  Barnyard character is subdued with some sweatiness and restrained brett notes.  Opaque tan-orange with no head.  Soured apricot with cheesey flavours in the finish.  Some leafy, herbal notes.  Quite acidic and puckering.  Some wheat character is apparent in the finish.  Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere at the Sunset Grill in Boston.

On tap the the Sunset Grill, only 5$! Calm headless amber hue shows orange-red hints. Aroma is enticing and funky with strong horsey, sweaty and barnyardy component. It definitely has a sweet connotation, honey-like blended with the horsey fruits (apricot, orange, pink grapefruit). Yep, this is a lambic, very fruity, limey, citric, lactic and funky. Yet, its aggressiveness is rather limited in mouth. Its tart of course, but pretty mellowed out. I assume the bottles are far more authentic in that regard, here, the mouthfeel is so lightly carbonated that it feels a bit lifeless.

With horseblanket, grapefruit, lemons, and a light fruit sweetness on the nose.. and the same on the mouth, I enjoyed this beer.  The beer poured a cloudy yellow color w/ thin lasting head and lacing.  The mouthfeel was light and carbonated.  MMMM... I love the Pizza Port Belgian Ale Fest.

On tap at the Sunset Grill. Slightly hazy golden orange body, medium head. Citrus and touches of apricot in the aroma, low on the lambic funk. A well-refined lambic, the apricot is subtle yet pleasant. The finish is the highlight of this beer, dry with a light woody and malt lingering taste. Yet another great Cantillon fruit lambic.

Pours with a cloudy gold body topped by a thin head with a surprisingly good amount of lacing.  Its incredibly sour and tart with notes of barnyard and a touch of apricot.  Dry as hell and light bodied.
on tap at the spuyten duyvil, brooklyn.  hazy yellow gold color, creamy off-white ring at the top.  musty and sour apricot nose.  low to no carbonation.  flavor is sour and dry apricot.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2007 mmmmm....This one has the perfect balance of sourness, but with a huge apricot flavor.   Aromad of apricots, funk,  citrus, and a litlle floral.  Flavors of the same, but with a mellow, dry, sweetness.

Draft at Monks... Poured a cloudy yellow color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of sweet apricots, tart lemons, and dry brettanomyces.  Taste was bone dry with a tart lemon, and sweet apricot taste.  Sour finish, the sweetness from the apricots was real nice.
Sour, but not too sour,  acidic and a hint of fruit in the finish, nose similar, color off golden, small head, pleasant yet not overly memorable.

On draught at Sunset Grille, Feb 2005.  Based on the qualities of my sample, Id say it was somewhere in the 2000-2002 vintage range.  Peach-apricot colored beer, with a small, fizzy white head, mostly disipating, with light lacing.  Quite hazy.  Aroma of light blue cheese, old funk, musty gym shoes and just an ever so slight hint of apricot essence.  Flavor is very relaxed, by Cantillon standards.  Sourness to start, but its much less aggressive and dominant than in some of their other beers.  A light amount of real apricot flavor (like biting in to a dried apricot) is well integrated with the tart, base lambic.  Notes of light cheese/bacteria and a bit of sweetness right near the finish.  Ends quite a good deal more sour than it starts, with plenty of yeast funk.  Delightful flavor throughout really showcases the lambic, with some apricot as an afterthought.  Medium body, no wateriness, very low carbonation, but just enough to please the palate and keep it refreshing and light.  I am definitely going to buy a bottle of this soon.

Well, Ive been buying this Cantillon stuff at premium prices and being largely disappointed.  This is another.  Hazy orange/amber with a fleeting champagne head.  Nose was acidic, citrus, sour, yearty.  Medium bodied, thin.  The flavor was sour, bitter, acrid, crappy.  Sorry, just not my style.

Ive been wanting to try this for a while and thanks to edward (brooklynboy) I was able to. Again, just too acidic and lambicy. I couldnt even pick out that this was apricot until I read the description.
Although its apricot it really tastes more like a Tangelo (grapefruit-orange hybrid). Definite saltiness too. Horse-blanket aroma as youd expect, but not over-powering.
UPDATED: MAY 14, 2007 Pale gold colored beer with a little head. Aromas of apricots and salt. Taste is very sour and salty, but while warming up turns over to a subtile sweet apricot tastes.

This is the BEST of the cantillons.  A shame we wont be getting them in Ontario anymore because allegedly they have too much arsenic according to LCBO standards.  Hazy peach/pink with a tartness that radiates through every inch of your being.  Dry finish, wine-like sensational on many levels.  Who knew apricot could be so fabulous?

pH=3. Decent aroma, light apricot notes, heavy gueuze yeast and wheat, with wet canvas or horse blanket. Hazy pale apricot amber-orange with no head. Medium body with heavy carbonation, carbonic burning. Extremely acidic throughout. Puckering tartness, almost beyond enjoyable. Typical Cantillon gueuze lambic profile with apricot notes throughout. The sourness of the apricots imparted even more sourness than usual, and I found this difficult to drink. Induced acid reflux.

Amazing Aroma, apricots, salt, that horse blanket sourness, and a gueuze like aroma kick.  Wow, this is an amazing aroma.  Ive lived at at house with an apricot trees my whole life, and perhaps that helps this beer.  Body is a pale gold, but appealing, with a thin layer of white bubbles covering the top of this lambic.  Taste is very sour, salty, but fades to a subtly sweet apricot/gueuze tastes.  Almost makes me roll my eyes.  This beer tingles the palate, and is amazing.  Wow, thats all I can say.

750ml bottle bought at the brewery. Aroma is sour, funky, slightly fruity. Flavour is sour and dry with noticeable fruit and is probably the sweetest Cantillon beer Ive had to date (which doesnt say much). Very nice.

Piercingly, brutally sour and not unlike a Berliner Weisse.  Shades of apricot in the nose, but very little in the flavor.  Dont buy this looking for a standard American fruit beer - its an unblended lambic left sitting in Bordeaux wine barrels for two years with evidently one apricot.  More of a citrus taste really - think lemonade without any sugar.  Fairly dry.  I should have saved the $30 and just bought a lemon.  More importantly, I felt this beer lacked the complexity of many of the previous Cantillon lambics that Ive had.  And the lack of apricot flavor was disappointing.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy yellow body with a moderate white head.  Tart aroma of white grapes, apples, and rhubarb.  Tart flavor with a dry finish.

750ml bottle from beersofeurope.co.uk. Cloudy yellow straw colour. Medium dissipating head, more sparkling than the Lou Pepes. Cheesy feet aroma with fruit, not immediately obvious that its apricot, quite lemony. Tastes gloriously sour with an extremely long acidic finish. Another cracker.

2000 Vintage:Very pale in color, light gold, with a head more like a a bottle conditioned beer than the typical honeycombed, champagne-like head of a lambic.  Aroma is typical Cantillon (barnyard, wet basement, and a big acid) with a touch of powdered sugar but no presence of apricots.  Acid overrides most of the palate but there are still remnants of what could best be described as Apricot Sweet-Tart(TM) candy enveloped in a slightly grainy though heavily bready malt.  This was very good, but I do not think it accomplished what it set out to do.

75cL bottle.  Clear with golden/yellow color.  Medium head.  The aroma is Cantillon all the way.  Plenty of sourness with horseblanket and funk.  It smells like a grapefruit. The flavor is pucker-quality sour!!!  It has grapefruit flavors with a touch of vinegar but it all blends together with the funk that is Cantillon.  You cant really taste the apricots but it does have a fruit quality that the gueuze doesnt have.  Excellent beer.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 Ah, my golden find. 9.99 for 75cl. And, its a 2001 bottle. Pours a fabulous pale yellow, very cloudy, thin white soaphead. Smells sour/tart. A little musty, stale hops, very little barnyard character, a little vinegar. Dry. Now to taste. Jawclenching sour. Oh sooo sour, and oh sooo good. Very geueze like, though a little lighter. Damn is this a fine lambic. Taste shows acid, lemon, actually a malt character. Finishes very dry. The Apricot comes out near the end, hidden by the acidity and by a touch of smoke, banana, cloves. Its hard to pick through the sourness, but theres a lot of wheaty flavors coming through. Damn fine!

On tap at Anam Caras Belgian Month.  Dark yellow orange with no head.  Sour fruit aroma.  Malty sour with some fruit.  My friend ordered this one and let me try it.  Im not a big fan of lambics, but this was pretty drinkable.  Not like those crappy sweet ones.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 Copenhagen beer marathon 2004, Golden color, heavy sour acid fruity aroma and taste, medium body, sour finish. 2-3-1-3-5.
Re-Rate. Bottle. A golden beer with no head. The aroma is light acid, sour and fruity with a hiny of barnyard, so is the taste, very dry. Medium body with a dry acid sour finish. 5-3-5-4-11.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 2008-05-31. Hazy yellow body, small white head. (3+) Musty, big peach aroma, touches of peach pits. (8+) Bracingly sour flavour blows out most of the fruit, but taking a largely sip and breathing in the aroma deeply finally brings out more of the peach near the end of the glass. (7+) Average palate is quite effervescent. (3+). Glad to try this one, it was much more palatable than my previous sample. I wonder if the fact that this was a large bottle and the other small made any difference? Bottle, Post-Mondial Tasting, Montreal 8/4/7+/3/16-17 - 3.9

October 2004. Bottle Beerbistro. Pours a hazy pastel yellow, with an orange hue to it. Little or no head. Slightly sweet musty fruit plays second fiddle to the sour lambic aroma. Big sour start kicks my tongues ass into consciousness. Refreshing, the acidity leaves my tongue watering in confusion. Sour tartness typical of Cantillon dominates the flavour, with pleasant but overwhelmed fruity highlights. Pithy notes in the finish. Spritzy effervescent body. Not my cup of tea. $20 on the pricey side for such a small bottle even if it is from the cellar collection. Consumption enjoyment was enhance by dodging Kimchee mint projectiles. ;) 6/3/6/3/14 - 3.2

Bottle, beer bistro.  Poured a syrupy orange with almost no head.  Acidic and slight fruity (apricot) aroma, but not overpowering.  Taste is sour for sure, but I was looking for a lot more apricot to balance it out - if I wanted to try the gueuze, I would have ordered it.  Still a wonderfully complex beer, but it just didnt grab me like I thought it would - I preferred the Rose De Gabrinus. Oh yeah, I thought the label was one of the best Ive ever seen.

Bottle at Smokeless Joes.  This was fantastic!  Orange-yellow cloudy beer with thin white lace.  Bright acidic aroma, oozes sweet apricot aroma, horseblanket, lactic/citric acid, leather.  Flavour is very sour, apricot flavour, but very dry.  Brett funkiness.  Very tasty.

Very cool label - fitting for a very good beer. orangey-amber haziness pours forth assaulting the nose with citrus sourness and apricot funkiness and some peachy tartness for good measure. The complexity doesnt end there though - flavours of the aforementioned fruits along with some puckering sourness through the delightful finish. Oh yeah baby.

750 ml bottle, at Monks in Philadelphia.  Light, hazy apricot color; subtle aromas of apricots, vanilla, coriander and the barest hint of brandy with an underlying farminess.  Massively, almost excruciatingly sour at first when lightly chilled -- nearly undrinkable even for this sourhead -- but when near room temp, the beautifully tart fresh apricot is joined by lime acid and some cidery notes.  Acid tingles endlessly at the finish.  Wonderful, though certainly not an everyday thing...but what great moments in life are?
