Cloudy apricot color w/thin white head. Peach, apricot, funk, citrus(light), and cantelope on the nose. Medium weight w/sour dry finish. Sour melon, fruit, peach, apricot, and light funk on the palate. Definatly one to share.

Pours straw yellow with a tiny quickly disipating soapy white head. Aroma of apple, peach, yeasty dough and citrus. Very acidic. Drying lemon juice, yeast, initially some saltiness. Soft toasted herbs, thyme and spice. Apple cider vinegar and must. Some vegetable stock I couldnt quite figure out, it didnt hurt it. Finish is puckeringly sour.

2000, Bottle 18/180.  Typical peppery sour Cantillon house aroma.  Peppery sour, no trace of fruit detectable.  Great full lambic flavor, horsey, and perhaps more sour than most.  Very funky.  Merest hint of apricots in the long sour finish.  Wonderful stuff.

Cantillon blows my mind. Pours a rich deep opaque straw hue. No head. The apricots really shine through. At first it smells like a trad. Gueuze, but then underneath it all a sweetness and hazy jamlike smell appears. The apricots fade into the flavor which is like a subdued Gueuze with small notes of sweetness. More sour than anything Ive had by Cantillon. Exceedingly sour. Exceedingly awesome.
G-rat

Hazy yellow orange body topped by a quickly collapsing white head. Lacing is nice. The aroma is musty barnyard and some apricot after it warms up a bit. The flavor is quite sour and acidic with the apricots being a secondary to tertiary element. Much less apricot then I was expecting. Medium bodied with a dry finish. Nice beer a nd very typical Cantillon. I would have preferred a bit more apricot, but really not much to comploain about.

Haxy cider gold.  Nice lacing, firm bubbly head had a nice lasting character to it.  Nose is quite sour and a bit funky, but not much in the way of apricot at first.  As it warmed, some apricot came around in the nose a bit, but really not enough that this is taking on a real apricot-esque character.  Flavor very, very sour and pungent, more sour than musty or funky, really no fruit to speak of at all, just mostly tart.  Would like more apricot in this, has promise of a fascinating flavor combo but just not that much fruit-wise going on.  Really more gueuze than anything.
Light apricot aroma with lots of great lambic almost overpowering it. Very sour and tart flavour with a pleasant and natural  apricot touch. Refreshing.
Slightly soured aroma.  Very acidic and soured...almost like lemonade left in the sun for 6 hours.  Not a favorite of mine.

Bottle: 2000 - #176 of 180. Cloudy light golden color with a moderate off white head and a touch of lace. Heavy aromas leading to te acidic brew that it is know to be. Touches of unripe fruit and rubber in the nose. Initial cobwebs and dust mixed with sour fruit. This can really clean the teeth. Dry and quenching to say te least in the finish. This is one of the roughest/toughest lambics out there. Small sips every few minutes seem to be the limit. Seems to peel the enamel off the teeth. Quite smooth and effervescent in feel. Long sour acidic finish. Heartburn in bottle. For me the fruit does not come out and the balance is off. I can appreciate the effort. The efforts here are more geared to creating the most sour brews, akin to the american most hoppy. Late lingers of mild hops and apricots do come out, but perhaps a touch to much suffering on the way.

Aroma of sour fruit, barnyard, wet blanket, cloudy apricot in colour, tiny white head. Quite tart, with flavour holding lemon, grapefruit and some yellow plum. Ultimately dry, but enjoyable. Really well done, kudos to Smokeless Joes for bringing this to town!

I shared a bottle with jerohen, thnx m8. Cloudy beige color, big head. Aroma is tart, notes of wood and apricot, but the typical gueuze tartness is very strong and dominant. Taste is extremely sour, very harsh and my jaws only stopped to react to this punishment of sourness after more than 5 mins. However, i could not wait to get another sip of this stuff!

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 Bottled in 2000, 0.7 liter (sampled 5th of june 2004). When trying to remove the cork it fell apart, but luckily the pressure inside opened the bottle itself. Ok, on to this fantastic beer. Great appearance, cloudy, trails of yeast, head as large as you want it to be. Immediately you can detect the strong typical gueuze aroma, tart, fruity, some oak, oh yeah this is good. First sip: whoa! This stuff is extremely sour, but fruity and complex as well. Surprisingly you just do not get used to the intense flavour, every sip is another explosion and it lasts and lasts. I dont think the apricot flavour is very obvious, and i think thats a good thing. May be my favourite lambic.

My first true Lambic and it was different. Nice orangey yellow colour and good aroma of apricots, but the aroma doesnt reveal the sourness. I think this is an acquired taste. Im glad I split this, the flavour is sour, but very natural apricots. You can tell they use real fruit. A good beer in small doses.

Good I split it with a friend and could have done so with three other friends.  After first acid bite on mouth (which I still feel 7 hours later), it grows on you.  Like a highly acidic apple.  A bit of apricot aroma but we tasted nothing sweet or fruity. Yeast but overpowered.  Recent arrival at Smokeless Joe's.  Bartender insists that's it, not skunked.
Cloudy orange with a frothy head dissolving to a ring of lace. Aroma is very fruity and sour. Flavour is tart but full of fruityness, very good.

Pours a peachy colored blond with a small white head. Aroma is SOUR apricot, leather, sweat, musty basement and wet cardboard. Some light wood as well. The taste is VERY SOUR! Youd think after 2 years in the bottle it would mellow some. Lemon and apricot along with more wood, and perhaps some sweetened undertones. The mouthfeel is sour and acidic. Finish was sour but not nearly as bad as I was thinking after the first sip. Very dry finish as well. Good beer, but this needed to age more to mellow it some.

Bottles 2001: Now this I like as opposed to the Bruoscella 1900 Grand Cru I just dumped. Hazy light orange hue with fizzy white head and some lace. The aroma as heavy horseblanket and dusty yeast esters, ripened cheese, light apricot and apple, vanilla bean, and pipe tobacco. The taste starts tart and woody with subdued fruits and vanilla undertones. Major acidic nature with a touch of hop leaf and woody finish. Lively and aggressive mouthfeel. BURP! Yep, this beer has the standard Cantillon pucker factor, but good depth of palate too. Not a good as the Lou Pepe line, but better than some of it siblings.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 (Draught) Opaque orange with a small head. Tart apricot aroma. Dry and tart flavor of apricot and sour apple. Medium body, slightly fizzy carbonation. Pleasantly tart, balancedly fruity-flavored lambic.
(Bottled, rated Apr 17, 2004, was 6-3-6-4-12=3.1) Hazy golden color, no head. Sour, fruity and acidic aroma. Very sour and crisp, fruity flavor. I cant find the apricot, but apple is present. Sour, sticky palate with smooth and long vanilla aftertaste. Some cantillon-typical stomach-acid present, but not too bad overall. The 0,375l bottle is way too big, though.

Stunning stuff, this.  I've had a fair few bottles and it just gets better and better with less fruitiness but more fruit acidity to challenge the palate.  It has a mesmerising nose of apricot and old straw with the usual lambic overtones and the flavour is uncompromisingly sour and acidic, yet balanced with soft, fleshy fruit and a strong leafy hop taste.  The long finish has fruit, a dry bitterness and an increasing grapefruity sourness.  Amazingly complex and packed with interest to reward the serious drinker, one of the best beers I've had.  (Bottle in Cantillon Brewery, Brussels)

Should be listed in the dictionary under "horseblanket".  Very strong odor of it and other barnyardy, cheesy, strong stuff.  Apricot aroma is detectable after it gets down to room temperature.  First sip is strongly acidic and almost putrid.  Cloying, thickens the palate with tangy, sticky saliva. Puckering, once it goes down.  Awesome and strong, this is no beginners lambic, but it also borders on too acidic, for the stomach starts to churn after my second glass. The apricot is tasty and fresh as it warms, I;ll enjoy the next bottle at room temp.  Superb if you are looking for an unusual lambic with strong chracteristics and mucho acidity. A fun after-dessert sipper.

The aroma is among the most Brett-laden cheesy of any lambic I've had, punctuated with slight sour whiffs of apricot and, as Ungstrup has noted, peach. Golden cloudy and luminescent. Thin islands of foam last like living breathing things. Unblended and higly sour, but also sweetens considerably when fully warm. Lemony yet soft. Certainly not sweet like a framboise is sweet.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: an unclear orange beer with a small head. The aroma is of sour milk. And so is the flavor, though combined with notes of peach. It has a very dry end. This is not my favorite fruit-lambic.
2004 SE Gathering: Very fruity sour apple flavor with strong grapefruit overtones. I can't detect any hops or malt in this one. Tastes like a sour fruity wine.

Cloudy yellow appearance. Lip pukering sour with apricots and lemons. This was my least favorite of all the Cantillons I sampled at the Atlanta gathering. But it is still another good lambic. Enjoyable if not great.
A musty golden appearance.  Apricots as an afterthought.  Alot sweeter than most of the Cantillon line.  Still very sour and musky, but very crisp in the finish.

Cloudy straw color,decent medium sized head that lasted for a good amount of time before fading to a small lace.The aroma was sourish,apricot and a little earthy.The flavor was much better then it let on,sweet and sour leaning more to the sour side with a nice apricot flavor maybe a hint of lemon with an apricot sour finish.Very nice brew much better then the kriek which i found to be a little over the top on the sour.This is a very much needed to be tryed brew for anyone who can get it.

Pours a golden orange color, slightly murky-very pretty.  Aroma is sharp and sour, very yeasty, almost no apricots detected.  The initial flavor is sharp and tart, still no apricots detected...at first, but as it begins to warm a definite sweet, fruity flavor of the apricots emerges.  A hint of vanilla makes the mouth feel warm, very nice.

Head is initially small, fizzy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly yeasty (barnyard), with notes of sour apple and cask wood. Flavor is moderately sweet, harshly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, harshly acidic. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, heavily astringent. Poorly balanced and too astringent IMHO...I like strong sourness in traditional lambic, of course, but Cantillon's products typically have little else going on.  This is no exception...light aroma, very stark and simplistic (or so it seems to me).  Girardin, Hanssens, Oud Beersel, etc. are all so much better IMHO.
Bottled in 2000, 4 years oldHazy golden color. Vinegar, mold, wood, cellar aroma. Harsh, astringent, woody; the fruitness is not easy to perceive.

Bottle from my Belgium trip.  Bright hazy yellow, very thin veneer of a smooth white head.  Pretty.  Aroma initially of barnyard, but quickly tempered by a clear citric apricot note.  In the mouth, there is an initial scorching knock of sourness, followed by barnyard funk, and ending with a surprising smooth, sweet flavor of almost pure fresh apricot.  I'm amazed at how clear an apricot flavor came through.  Amazing stuff.

Treble blond colour, whithout head.  Sour, rotten aroma.  Sour flavour, sweet in the end.  Very special beer.  Now I'm glad I spent so many money on it, (but not as many as in the USA), I payed 5 euro in the brewery.

hazy as hell apricot color. thin head...thicker at the edges. some sediment. my nose detects more vinegar than fruit and a tiny bit of fresh asphalt smell that i seem to get with the Oude Beersel line. very tart flavor. extremely crisp and acidic. this may be the most tart example to date for me. positively sends the salivary glands into overload...just what i'm looking for. but at the $27.99 price tag on the 750ml bottle, i probably wouldnt buy it again.
Hazy pink grapefruit body, apricots hidden in a stable aroma.  Strong sitrussy flavor, bigger acidity than Lou Pepe, some saltiness.  Cheers Kasta!
Cloudy dark blond geuze with no head. Aroma of apricot-peach. Lovely complex fruity sourness and a wonderful complex palate. Fruity, sour and dry aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 August 2009 Bottled on date; Sampled July 2010
The beer pours with a hazy, sedimented, mucky color due to the completely crap pour by the waitress.  It is topped by a fizzy, short lived, white head.  The aroma is very tart smelling at first, but yields to notes of apricots, a hint of yeast and then back to tart again.  Musty aromatics are joined by notes of musky barnyard notes as well as some catty, urea like notes.  The nose really has a nice, floral / fruit apricot character to it that makes this vibrantly aromatic.

The flavor is bracingly sour upfront and finishes with a softer apricot like acidity that is joined by lactic acid sourness too.  A floral apricot flavor is definitely here, despite the beer being bone dry.  The body is quite light and refreshing and is definitely a beer meant for consuming in quantity (assuming you can get past the sourness of course).  This is very nice, I would have loved to be able to try an even fresher example
Sampled July 2004, 2001 bottling.
Pours a very hazy orange-gold color.  The head is cream colored and dissapears after a couple of minutes.  The aroma is tart and funky.  It is quite sour with some muted barnyard Brett notes.  As is usual with Cantillon the taste is at first shockingly mouth puckering.  After all of this time I dont even get a sense of the apricots.  A bit of chalkiness is in the middle of this beer, which seems to add a bit of fullness to this otherwise light and refreshing beer.  The sourness is reminiscent of grapefruit and lemons.  Though I really wish there was some apricot flavor here, it is still quite good, though just as a Lambic.
Sampled 2002
A orangish light gold color to this beer, that is more light gold than anything.  Pours with a lively carbonation.  I cant detect any apricot in the aroma, though there is a slight fruitiness, but mostly smell sour.  The taste is of course quite acidic, with general musty character as well.  If I did not know this beer I would have no idea that it was made with apricots.  The lambic beasties have completely obliterated all signs of the apricots.  As a lambic type beer this is quite good, though seems a bit simplistic compared to some of the other offerings.  Tastes more of a citrus type fruit, which comes from the acidity.  I am a bit dissapointed in the apricot character from this beer, but it is still quite good.

Hazy yellow/gold. Slight, frothy yellow head. Light aroma of apricot, barnyard, & tart lemony citrus. Light, dry feel. Very sweet apricot flavour up front. Gives way to a leathery, earthy, cidery tartness.
Cloudy , citussy . Sour but also what is important to metion -earthy . Tart front , midlle earty and mellows at the end .

hazy yellow.  spritzy earth, tart and mild peachy aroma.  tastes way more sour than it smells with with lots od cider vinous and vinegary notes.  peaches and apricots play back up and are always there, but aren't quite a foil for the extreme sour.  ends dry and earthy.  very nice.

Bottle at GBBF 2003  Hazy vomit colour. Shit and acid aroma. Acidic up front, quite sharp and unpleasant. Middle is beech and oak wood. Finish returns sharp and dry. Probably the worst lambic I've had. Nuffield will now send me a message saying how much he hates me....

Bottle at GBBF.  Hazy yellow with a big, dense head.  Big gueuze barnyard flavors, sour palate--wow, pucker me baby!  Very enjoyable effect.  Yet, it is smooth.  As I'm drinking it Rauchbier points out that the label says it has apricots.  What?  Let me look for them....well, like the Dogfish Head Aprihop, the apricot is a little hard to find, but then yes, in a Melbourn Brothers way it is there.  A big thanks to BeerLimey for opening his bottle of this.

Beer # 3 at Todd's Continents Collide party. Appearance is of crushed pineapple with a dash of apricot mixture with a medium size short lasting white head. Elusive complex aroma - skin and barnyard yeast, citrus flowers and hint of egg white, minimal fruit. Wonderful medium sour grapefruit-lemon and yeast with decent touch of stone fruitiness and marzipan flavours. Medium light crisp lifting sour finish turning to mild bitter in the aftertaste. This has to be one of my favourite lambics.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2017 Bottles : A juicy, airy apricot perfume riding citrusy, bready dough... Fresh lemon juice splashes, as a prickly body lashes... The inflation of ideas had commenced, but sadly my glass cried empty laments...I need more!!...8/4/9/5...17/20

On tap : Medium sourness within a flat, unblended-like body...Fruitiness is not quite distinctive and sourness levels encourage drinking and quenching...8/3/8/3...15/20
Murky orange in colour.  Aroma is sour, tart, citrus, peaches.  Flavour is sour, sweet, peaches.  Finishes tart and dry.
(WCC2003):  Cloudy peach body.  Aroma is sour barnyard, peach, cheese.  Taste is sour, cheese, tart, light peach, moderately strong horseblanket.  Acidic medium body.

(75o ml Bottle) Sour citrus, apricots and dry white wine. Cloudy orange body that is similar to grapefruit juice. Tart finish to a sweet start - like many relationships. But OH what a sour finish! Thanks Kasta for bringing this to the Continents Collide Party.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2004 Bottled. GBBF2003. Hazy gold, low head and condition. Mouldy fruit piled up under a tree in a cow field, in the summer sun. Quite sweet and fruity but well balanced by the intense brett notes and a pleasant saltiness. Finish has intensly dry fruity skin notes.
Dense light clouded yellow appearance. Lots of cheese in the aroma, apple and vinegar. Cheesie flavor, sour from start to finish, astringent and puckering at the end.

If there was a Lambic Man, akin to Kool-Aid man, when he encountered this one he'd surely ejaculate his characteristic "Oh, yeah!" (or would that be, "Ah, oui"?). Cloudy straw color, fizzy white head. Nose is pronounced--sour, with lots of barnyard hints--cut grass, livestock, hay--and just a bit of apricot in their. Flavor is sour, almost salty. Nice touches of apricot give it a delicious roundness. Grass, hints of sweetness, but very dry. Finishes with a wonderful lemony tartness. Oh yeah.

Apricot lambic.  Again, as with most of the Cantillon fruit lambics, the apricot flavours is not apparent buit it makes the harsh Cantillon gueuze a little tamer, smoothing the rough edges out a little.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2012 2001 Vintage:  Cloudy banana.  Dazzling white, creamy froth.  Surprisingly soft aroma of clay, tea leaf, lemon, glue, passionfruit, soured oranges, sharp iron notes, bandage, and fresh cracked grains.  Vague earthy hop, apricot, bubblegum, and soft strawish, pale malt shades.  Only slightly musty.  Soft, fuzzy mouthfeel with a medium body.  Puckeringly sour flavors, although less firm and irony than its counterparts.  Lingering iron and bandage notes trailed by apple skin, honeydew melon, peach, and a lovely, highly subtle pale malt base.  Finishes bone dry.  The aroma showcases Gueuze qualities and somehow manages to simultaneously display raw cracked grains and beautiful fruity subtleties.  The sour flavors are prominent, and the pale malts are elegantly understated.  Less ironish and musty than its peers, but this epitomizes Lambic brilliance in an unprecedented fashion.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: pale, cloudy yellow w/ a  horribly sour flavor. I detect absolutely NO apricot. There's no sweetness like the others have mentioned. Drain pour.

Poured a brilliant and opaque golden orange color with a frothy, white head.  A nice fruity aroma of peaches and apricots.  Before drinking, I almost forgot this was a lambic.  The first sip jump-started me back to reality and clarity.  Certainly more tame than a gueuze, this still has plenty of dry and sour elements with a throat-puckering tartness.  The sweetness of the fruit does a wonderful job of balancing the lambic base.  A tasty and well-made beer.

On tap: Itty, bitty bubbles cling together to form a melted ice cream head on top of the fuzzy golden orange body inside of the tall goblet.  The aroma is palpable: a thick juicy apricot wedge dripping sticky juices through my fingers. . . I plunge my teeth into the seculant flesh and it bursts into my mouth, sucking the saliva from my tongue. . . the wonderful sensation leaves all corners of my mouth dripping with anticipation for the next bite.  A rare treat on a warm spring evening at the Hop Leaf.

On tap at the Map Room in Chicago served in a goblet: Golden color with a lightly lacing head.  Great subtle peachy aroma.  Dry woody robust body with a great peach balance and a touch of sourness.  Finish is tart and fruity, but not overly acidic like many lambics.  This is a classy, refined, and enjoyable brew.

Light amber in color.  This beer has a great nose, with musty, acidic notes that are toned down by the fruit.  At first I couldnt sense much apricot, but after drinking side-by-side with another gueze, the apricots really are apparent.  Not an incredibly sour beer with more fruit in finish than anywhere else.

golden to yellow body with lots of rocky white head.  the nose is fantastic, the characteristic lambic, gueuze nose with lots of apricot wafting through.  the flavor was the only dissapointment because the apricot did not show up quite as much as i had hoped.  still a great lambic sourness and flavor but i would have liked more apricot flavor after smelling this beer.  the label is exceptionally beautiful as well, i would buy it just for the label, but thankfully the beer inside is quite good too.

Everytime I try it I ask myself why I go back for more? This has got to be the most cour thing I've ever tried from Cantillon. Small indication of Apricot on the nose but the citric acids meet with the lambic tartness to create an overpowering sourness that gives me pucker face every time. I like it and I don't really understand why!
Nice cloudy golden look to it.  Very sour, Apricot, apples, A good tartiness, Very impressive, has a nice apple aroma to it also.

Lemon yellow bodt with some rocky pure white foam.  Nice laceing throughout the galss.  Lots of horse blanket, lemons, apricot and sweet cream in the nose along with the promise of lambic tartness and yet not so over the top as others from Cantillon.  Citric acid tartness is par for couse and tempered by a lush mothfeel that is accented by flavors of candied apricot and cream,  Begins to pick up green notes along the way imparting a little herbal bitterness.  Finishes with a fresh burst of lambic tartness.

Colour of orangey-gold, slight haze. Nose gives some smoke, a fruity type that is indeed apricot-like, above the classical wet-wood, horseblanket smell. In the taste however, no apricot or peach, rather something spicey, meaty even. If any fruit would come to the fore, I'd say physalis ("pineapple-cherry"). Lots of lactic acid, al little acetic. Mouthfeel is velvety (quite appropriate), but with a sharp finish. JP Van Roy apologisez: "It isn't traditional, but it is pleasing." He's right.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 yellow brilliance and thick white head were taking over this big long flute of mine..aromas of leather, barnyard, swiss cheese, sweat, and maybe subtle apricots..not much carbination here unfortunately, although there is some..the sourness and acidic lemony zeal combine nicely..puckering finish..very subdued apricot flavor..no sweetness, which is a good thing..more leathery notes come through in the flavor and aftertaste...a nicely balanced and very dry classy beverage..

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2003 Light, pleasant nose, only slightly fruity (citrus). Hazy orange color, fizzy at first,  but then no head. The apricot makes for a great lambic - fab blend!Extremely sour as expected - puckering finish that is kinda chalky too. Pretty big body for this brewer. It is not so candy-like as with kriek, and not so sour as with gueuze. Get this if you can.

Light apricots smell, again the typical cantillon nose is coming through and hits you - clong - on your head.  Orange body with a foamy head. Fizzy carbonation. Sour - of course, apricot. Nice dry wine like, spritzy too. Was perfect with the salmon I made for dinner. i think it this is my favourite Cantillon.

Sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden.
Dark yellow, hazy, no head. Aroma of citric acid. Lightly fruity, mostlt sour. Firm maltiness, some apricot and syrup in the finish. But still - this is hardcore lambic, and just on the border of what my stomach can possibly accept.

cloudy orange colour, few head, very complex aroma (vinegar, floral, rhubarb and apricot), very sour and light acid with a very brutal dry finish - not an easy beer (like all from Cantillon) and not the best Cantillon.

Beautiful, glorious lambic. I agree with eczematic.. it manages to smell like horseshit and apricots at the same time.. Rotting cheese also comes to mind. The taste is glorious: subtle apricot notes are quickly overwhelmed by Cantillons signature aggresive tartness...

i should have heeded the weirdo tour guides suggestion that you neednt have more than a couple of glasses of this stuff as after this i got some pretty serious stomach problems. glad that it wasnt too sweet anyway
hazy pale orange. smell = equal parts dried apricots and shit. big sour juicy apricot taste fills your mouth and then tweaks into funky lambicity.
Sampled at Cantillon brewery: Pretty bloody good stuff, slight apricot sweetness in the start, but dry, sour and tart finish, tremendoulsy refreshing, and very well balanced.

Bottled in 2000. Apricot and oak in the aroma. Very sour taste with oak, apricot, lemon, grapefruit. Absolutely no sweetness left. Long finish with lots of citric sourness. Brilliant beer!! Only misses the intense depth of a well matured geuze.

The aroma is amazing, light apricot, oak, fruity. Hazy, golden/yellow/amber colour. Small white frothy head. Very sour (almost too harsh), very oak and tart. Fruity. In the flavors the apricot is gone. Short finish, sour and dry.
Bursting with sweet fruit, then bringing in a great undercut of lambic tartness.  Well structured.
